PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:-
That there is widespread community concern about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia
Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:-
1. Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia and
2. Ban the import of Cobalt-60 and Caesium 137 and Caesium 134 to be used to irradiate food products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights and Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:-
1. That the Bill of Rights will have the power to override and negate our Common Law within five years of its enactment.

2. Because the Bill of Rights is based on an International Covenant, this will take the control of our country out of the hands of the people and their democratically elected representatives, giving the power to those outside Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
1. That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights and all cognate Bills.
2. That as our representatives, you protest our Australian Heritage and Christian culture and values, both in the Education System, and through the Media.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Islander Languages: Funding for Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
(a) Aboriginal and Islander languages, which numbered approximately 260 when Europeans first arrived, are even more seriously endangered-already 145 have become extinct.
(b) English-speaking population expansion and English-speaking mass media expansion threatens the survival of the remaining languages of Australia.

(c) Aboriginal languages reflect an ethos that is truly Australian and unless steps are taken to implement language maintenance, this ethos will be lost not only to Aborigines but to non-Aboriginal Australians, and to the world.
We humbly pray the Government to:

1. Through the Prime Minister's Department, provide $300,000 per annum for a guaranteed period of ten years to enable the Aboriginal community of Australia to establish a co-ordinating body to implement steps to prevent the extinction of the remaining languages, and to introduce programmes which will enable these languages to continue into the future for the sake of all Australians. This body will enable us to maximize existing financial, material, and human resources, and is the least expensive way of implementing urgently needed maintenance programmes.
2. Through the Prime Minister's Department, provide finance for the establishment of Regional Language Centres-ten are urgently needed-cost $200,000 each.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purposes for our Nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there is a need for an independent and multi-cultural broadcasting corporation to give a firm legislative and financial basis for the SBS network.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should pass Senator Vigor's Bill with all expediency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects, namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Capital Gains Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled, the petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth opposition to cuts in English as a Second Language (ESL) teaching, the scrapping of the multicultural education program, the amalgamation of the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), and the abolition of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs (AIMA), as announced in the Federal Budget of August 19, 1986.
Your petitioners request that the government will review and reverse its decisions on these matters.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that it is my intention after Question Time to withdraw Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in my name for the disallowance of the Children's Services Ordinance 1986 as contained in the Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 13 of 1986. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has been scrutinising the Children's Services Ordinance 1986, which is a long, detailed and very significant ordinance dealing with the welfare of children in the Australian Capital Territory. The Committee raised with the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) a number of concerns under its principles of scrutiny. It also held two in camera hearings with, among others, the Chief Magistrate of the Australian Capital Territory, and the Law Reform Commissioner upon whose report the ordinance is based.

SPEECH.PARA: The matters of concern to the Committee related to the following issues: Uncontrolled extensions of the powers of the youth advocate; the need for representative membership of the Children's Services Council; the need for a magistrate to have discretion to deal with certain defendants over 18 years of age whose alleged offences occurred before that age; reasonable limits on police powers to enter premises and determine who should be present when a child is interviewed; the need for parents to be told where a child is being held in custody; the need for express protections when identifying material like blood or fingerprints is to be taken from a child; the power of the police and the youth advocate to hold a child in detention for up to 48 hours before there arises any need for judicial intervention; the need for parents to have a right to apply to a court to seek the release of a child as soon as it is taken into custody as allegedly being in need of care; the need for a right of appeal to a magistrate against certain administrative decisions touching on the religious interests of a child; the need for law enforcement officers to carry and use proper photographic identity cards; the need to ensure that before a child is removed from an un- licensed child minder the parents will be warned that this will happen rather than learn of it after the event; the provision of Administrative Appeals Tribunal review of certain decisions affecting applicants for licences to be a child care provider; and, finally, the need for the tabling in Parliament of State-Territory agreements on child care.

As the Senate will realise, the Committee has conducted a quite extensive review of this Ordinance under its limited principles of scrutiny. Indeed, the Minister for Territories and his private office and departmental staff have extended to the Committee a quite outstanding measure of co-operation, advice and assistance with this task, and they have done so with the dual commitment to protect children's interests as well as their rights. The Minister has undertaken to make a number of very important changes to the Ordinance in the interests of protecting, as far as reasonably possible, the rights of individuals, including parents, but particularly the rights of children, who are the Minister's paramount concern in relation to this Ordinance.

The Committee, having scrutinised the Ordinance more thoroughly than it has scrutinised any previous legislation in recent times, has no further objection to it under its principles. The Minister has given undertakings to amend the Ordinance, and he is to be commended for the way in which he has dealt with the Committee and ultimately acted decisively to protect rights. For the public record, I think it would be proper to table the Committee's correspondence on this important legislative scrutiny. I therefore seek leave to table these documents.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I indicate to the Senate that I do not wish Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 1 relating to the Children's Services Ordinance 1986 to be withdrawn, and I wish my name to be put on the notice of motion. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Cooney has pointed out to the Senate, the Children's Services Ordinance 1986, relating to the manner in which children in the Australian Capital Territory will be dealt with, is a very significant step in the handling of the welfare of children. I wish to take over this notice of motion because the Opposition has some reservations about the number of issues of policy relating to the Ordinance. The Ordinance is, as I have said, very important for the welfare of the most vulnerable group of people in our society-our children. Indeed, it breaks much new ground, and for that reason it is necessary that the very novel mixture of legal, administrative and judicial procedures contained in the Ordinance does not operate in any way that is detrimental to children.

SPEECH.PARA: For that reason and because of a range of quite new and experimental initiatives in the Ordinance, the Opposition has decided that the operation of the order and its effects on children should be subject to a genuine ongoing review. I have asked the Minister for Territories, Mr Scholes, who, as Senator Cooney has pointed out, has been very co-operative with the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and whom I believe will be co-operative with me, to subject the Ordinance to a four-year sunset clause to ensure that such a fundamentally important piece of legislation is subjected to a mandatory review and, if necessary, overhaul after a reasonable period of operation. I have discussed this matter with Senator Vigor, and I understand that the Australian Democrats agree with the Opposition parties that a four-year sunset clause should be inserted. Indeed, it is my belief that members of the Government also believe that there ought to be a four-year sunset clause. Accordingly, I am waiting on the Minister's final response in relation to this proposal. I believe that some time during the day the Minister will indicate to me agreement to insert a four-year sunset clause into the Ordinance, so it is probable that later today I will be seeking to withdraw the notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I can put Senator Lewis out of his misery right now. I am advised by the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) that, while he is happy, after a period of four years, to set in train a major review of the operation of the Children's Services Ordinance, he is not willing to accede to any suggestion that the Ordinance contain a sunset clause. There are a number of reasons for that basic stance, the most basic of which, I suppose, is that in the event that the legislation were to terminate at the end of that period- and there are all sorts of contingencies with which we are all entirely familiar which could result in the sunset clause taking effect without continuity arrangements having been put in place-not only would there not be the new apparatus of administrative and welfare-type provisions to which Senator Lewis has drawn attention but also there would not be any Children's Court at all and no powers in existence to protect abused or neglected children.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking here about a combination of machinery and rules which are really quite fundamental for the protection of children in this society. We are not talking about some body, such as the Commission for the Future or the Human Rights Commission, or the other statutory authorities responsible for particular programs, about which there may be concern expressed from time to time and a reasonable desire to scrutinise thoroughly, against the backgrounds of the discipline of a sunset clause, their continued existence. We are talking about something absolutely fundamental to the effective administration of this society, and we believe that a sunset clause, whether it is to operate as originally proposed by Senator Lewis after two years, which would have been totally inappropriate because of the way in which this legislation is being phased in over time and the need to accumulate a body of experience in its application, or whether we are talking about a longer period, such as four years, for the reasons I have indicated the newly fashionable mechanism of a sunset clause is simply inappropriate in this particular context.

I give the undertaking on behalf of the Minister for Territories that there will be a full-scale review of this legislation, but not in the context, for the reasons I have mentioned, of a sunset clause. Whatever private deal Senator Lewis might have had with the erratic Senator Vigor which may have come unstuck, that is a matter for Senator Vigor and the Australian Democrats to untangle with him. I can say, however, on behalf of the Government that the position is as I have described. The Minister is not prepared to accede to any such request. There is no point in delaying until a later hour this day consideration of this motion. If Senator Lewis wants to go ahead and move the motion, I suggest that he do so and that we put the matter to a vote and determine it here and now.

STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1986

Volume 4 of the Report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC) for the 1985-87 Triennium was tabled in the Parliament on 22 October 1986. The Report responds to the Government's Supplementary Guidelines announced on 19 August 1986, and makes recommendations on the distribution of additional funds for universities, colleges of advanced education and institutes of tertiary education for 1986 and 1987, and the Commonwealth's contribution to TAFE systems for 1987. This Bill gives effect to the Government's decisions on the Report.
The Bill seeks appropriation of an additional $414.7 million comprising:

$19.6 million in additional grants for higher education for 1986 and 1987, including recurrent grants for The Western Institute in Melbourne, the first institute of tertiary education within the Commonwealth programs of assistance for tertiary education:
$305.7 million for the TAFE sector in 1987; and
$89.4 million for adjustments for cost increases to existing grants for all sectors consistent with Government policy on retrospective cost supplementation for education grants.

The distribution of the additional higher education grants for 1986 and 1987 is as recommended by CTEC. The key features of the increased triennial program for the States and Northern Territory for higher education are:

a further increase of intakes of some 3,000 in 1987, 1,000 more than previously planned. In total an additional 29,600 higher education places will have been created over the triennium. Some 90 per cent of the new intakes in 1987 will be directed to courses relevant to future economic growth, in particular, engineering, applied science, computing, economics and business studies;

200 of the new places in 1987 will be set aside for Aborigines which, together with the intakes and provisions made in earlier years, will result in some 1,050 places being earmarked for Aborigines in 1987;

50 places will be provided for initiatives in higher education in Northern Queensland involving co-operative arrangements between TAFE colleges in Mackay and Cairns and James Cook University of North Queensland and Capricornia Institute of Advanced Education, respectively;

40 places will be provided for higher education initiatives in North-West Tasmania involving co- operative arrangements between TAFE colleges in Devonport and Burnie and the University of Tasmania and the Tasmanian State Institute of Technology;
a contribution of $0.75 million will be made towards the construction of the Macquarie University Graduate School of Management; and

the Special Assistance for Students Program is to be extended to include students in advanced education courses in institutes of tertiary education, at TAFE institutions and at Northern Territory tertiary education institutions.

In the TAFE program for 1987, increased funding will be provided for fees reimbursement grants, from $96.8 million in 1986 to $102.7 million in 1987, while designated grants for special course provision and equipment grants will be maintained at the same real level as in 1986. An additional $4.0 million will be made available in 1986-87 for minor works and equipment to assist in the provision of the off-the-job training component of the Australian Traineeship System.

TAFE capital grants totalling $138.3 million will be provided for 1987. This amount includes funds to commence construction of 16 new projects and designs of 7 new projects as well as providing further funding for 51 continuing projects.

The Bill also provides for continuing support for the concept of ``institutes of tertiary education'' as multi-sector institutions. Recurrent funds for 1986 and 1987 are provided for the first such institute, the Western Institute in Melbourne, under a new category of recurrent grant. A grant of $0.2 million is provided as an initial contribution towards the construction of facilities for the Western Institute. The Commonwealth will be contributing $2 million to this project with the balance-at least $2 million-to be provided by the Victorian Government. This new institution, to provide both TAFE and higher education courses, will be an important advance in expanding education opportunities for people in the western suburbs of Melbourne.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Act 1983 to supplement for cost increases the grants available to government and non-government education authorities in the States and the Northern Territory to conduct projects and programs under the Participation and Equity Program in the years 1986 and 1987. The Bill also provides new schedules for 1987 showing the allocation of funds to the States, the Northern Territory and the education sectors.

The cost supplementation proposed is in accord with the Government's undertaking to provide retrospective cost supplementation for this program. The adjustments are consistent with those being made to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) and States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bills which are also before the House today.

The financial impact of this Bill will be to provide an additional $0.741 million in 1986 and an additional $1.476 million in 1987. Total provision for the Participation and Equity Program is $43,987,000 in 1986 and $44,722,000 in 1987.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986

The main purposes of this Bill are to amend the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1984 to implement decisions in the recent Budget on Commonwealth programs for schools in 1987 and to supplement for cost increases grants already appropriated for schools programs.

The detailed appropriations for specific purpose and capital programs for government and non-government schools in each State and the Northern Territory give effect to the Government's decisions on the Commonwealth Schools Commission's Report for 1987 which was tabled on 22 October 1986.

The 1984 Act already contains the per capita grants under the General Recurrent Program for government and non-government schools for the period 1985-88. This comprehensive long term program was retained intact in the recent Budget and continues to provide authorities with stability and security in the planning of school operations.

In the area of the Commonwealth's special education programs for the handicapped, the Government has accepted the Commission's proposals for the restructuring of some programs. This will entail the integration, into a joint program, of the existing separate elements for Early Special Education, and the establishment of single State level committees to co-ordinate the administration and allocation of funds for this program along with programs for Special Education Services, Severely Handicapped Children, Children in Residential Institutions and Special Education Recurrent Grants for Non-government Schools.

The Government has also accepted the Commission's proposals for phasing in over a number of years more equitable bases for the distribution of funds for these programs between States and Territories so that allocations will closely reflect the needs of groups being assisted.

For the English as a Second Language General Support Program, the Bill incorporates an additional $4 million in 1987 to support English language teaching. These funds have been distributed between government school systems in the States and Territories on the basis of the number of students of non-English speaking background, the same basis as that used for the existing program.

In relation to the out of hours element of the Ethnic Schools Program, the Schools Commission recommended that, in the context of the development of a National Language Policy, further consideration be given to the continued administration of this element as a ``Schools'' program. At the present time, given the advanced stage of work on a National Language Policy, the Government does not propose to accept this recommendation.

The Bill appropriates $1.8 million for the Projects of National Significance Program in 1987 and approval of allocations for particular activities under the provisions of the Act will be determined by the Minister in the normal way.
All the other recommendations of the Commission in its Report for 1987 have been approved by the Government.

The Bill also provides for a number of technical amendments. These include a requirement for government and non-government school authorities to provide appropriate recognition of the funding provided by the Commonwealth in respect of building and equipment projects for the Commonwealth in respect of building and equipment projects for schools serving predominantly Aboriginal Communities; provision for non-government schools and systems to furnish original documents, if required, relating to the accountability provisions under the general recurrent grants program; and provisions to enable the results of amalgamations or separations of schools to be included on the list of non-government schools for grant purposes.

The financial impact of this Bill will be to appropriate an additional $19 million for 1986, $418 million for 1987 (bringing total funding for 1987 programs to an estimated $1614 million), and an additional $47 million for 988. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Regulation 4 of the Companies Regulations (Amendment) 1986, as contained in Statutory Rules 1986 No. 247 and made under the Companies Act 1981, be disallowed.

The purpose and effect of this motion would be to disallow new regulations made under the Companies Act which came into force on 1 October last. Their main purpose is to repeal the existing schedule of those regulations and to substitute a new schedule. This new Schedule is a massive document, appended to part of the new regulations. It deals with new accounting rules for companies. As I said, the purpose of this motion is to disallow the new schedule. Even though the new schedule is the major part of these new regulations, it is, in fact, only part of them. The Senate, of course, has the power to disallow part of a regulation even though it cannot amend it.

The difficulty that the Opposition faces in this matter is that we do not disagree with the whole of the new Schedule. It is good in parts. Unfortunately it has some grave deficiencies and it is not possible to move amendments to the Schedule under the existing power that we have to disallow regulations. The Opposition is having to move the disallowance of the whole of the new Schedule in the hope that if that is successful the Government and Ministerial Council will adopt a new approach to this whole question of enforcing accounting standards. The new schedule has some favourable features, the main one of which is a reduction in the reporting requirements for the majority of companies and in particular exempt proprietary companies, which cover 90 per cent of all companies. The reduction in the reporting requirements is welcomed by the Opposition. We do not object to that but unfortunately we cannot separate that from our other objections to the Schedule.

Our main objection is that there are much greater disclosure requirements for large companies which are defined as listed corporations, borrowing corporations and companies other than exempt proprietary companies with gross assets exceeding $10m or gross operating revenue exceeding $20m a year. They will be required to disclose a great deal of information about the directors' and executives' total remuneration, significant trading relationships, superannuation provisions, valuations of assets and relationships with associated businesses and other corporations. These new requirements have brought strong objections from a whole range of organisations and people involved in the administration of companies. In particular they have come from leading business organisations such as the Business Council of Australia, the Institute of Directors, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the professional accounting bodies and the Australian Accounting Research Foundation, which is a most prestigious organisation supporting accounting standards. There has been very serious objection from experts in the field and it is clearly a case where the Ministerial Council and the Government should think again.

The Schedule itself has been developed through the Ministerial Council, which means the State and Commonwealth companies offices. It is not a scheme which has been developed through the accounting bodies themselves and its professional accounting standards research body, and it has not been developed through the Government's ministerial scheme of final approval to accounting standards being given by the Accounting Standards Review Board, the annual report of which has only recently been tabled in this Parliament by the Government. I refer to that report because it sets out the valuable and important work being done by this new statutory body. Its establishment has been a major development in company law in recent years and has received the approval of the Ministerial Council and of this Parliament. That is the proper way in which accounting standards should be developed and approved. Yet here we have a completely different approach-the old fashioned approach of strict legislative, convoluted, complex regulations which have been a feature in this area of accounting standards in company law in the past. This development is now provided for, yet the new Schedule follows the old approach and seems totally to ignore the new approach foreshadowed by the establishment of the Accounting Standards Review Board.

The Opposition has objections to the way in which this has been done and it has objections to the approach of Schedule 7. The Government's approach maintains great legal complexity and detailed legislation rather than establishing standards. It imposes strict formats for profit and loss accounts and balance sheet requirements and these are inconsistent with the approach that has been made, particularly in Canada and the United States, which are the two countries at the forefront of accounting research. This pro forma type reporting has also been rejected in New Zealand and the United Kingdom. Indeed, the only major group with our form of company law and regulation which seems to be adopting this is the European Economic Community.

The exposure draft itself has not been given sufficient consideration. There has not been sufficient time given to its consideration. It was developed through the Ministerial Council, which means the companies officers of the various States and the Commonwealth. It was made available to the professions and to business in December 1985 and submissions on it had to be made by 28 February 1986. That was a very short period. It is also a very unsatisfactory time of the year for any bodies to be able to devote to full consideration of matters of this complexity. Indeed, the bodies did reply and, as a result of their comments, major changes and improvements were made in the exposure draft. Nevertheless there are these major deficiencies still in the Schedule.

I wish to deal briefly with the major deficiencies that we see, even assuming that we thought this was the right approach. However, I want to emphasise that we in the Opposition believe that this is the wrong approach. The major defects relate to the new and greatly expanded disclosure required of major corporations and particularly the disclosure of salary packages of the directors of listed corporations and of the five most highly paid executives of those corporations. Again, these requirements go far beyond those of other countries and a large enterprise that comes within the definition of a listed corporation will obviously have a number of subsidiaries, even sometimes inoperative subsidiaries. Senior executives at various levels in a company of that size tend to be directors of subsidiary companies. These requirements for disclosure of the remuneration of directors of those companies and of the five most highly paid executives could result in disclosure of remuneration packages of literally hundreds of executives. This will not apply just to the senior executives; it will go right down to the middle management of these companies and hundreds of executives will have their salary packages-not just their remuneration-required to be disclosed. They will be identified by name and, as I have said, the full details of their salaries will be provided. Of course, the provision not only will make it far more onerous for the company but also it will result in public knowledge of salary levels within the corporation to a great extent.

We can well understand the reasons why this Government wants to be so intrusive but the extraordinary irony is that on the very day we are debating this matter this Government has introduced a privacy Bill which no doubt we will be debating shortly. On the one hand, the Government is recognising a principle of privacy-albeit in a limited fashion but nevertheless it is giving legislative recognition to people's privacy requirements and their feelings-yet here, on the other hand, it is breaching in a most intrusive way what is essentially private information about people working for private companies, not even for governments. This will also probably have the ironic effect of creating greater increases in salary levels in the corporate sector. People will know what companies are paying, creating problems because of the move for comparative wage injustice that has become endemic in the community, with the encouragement of the trade union movement and Australian Labor Party governments. In the opinion of the business community this sort of information will result in an overall increase in salary levels in the corporate sector. These sorts of price lists will give executive search firms a field day.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they do not have to have the individual executive amounts, only an aggregate.

—The point is they have to provide the directors' salaries, and quite minor executives often become directors of subsidiary companies. That is the point I was making earlier. So altogether it is a very intrusive provision and, apart from the breaching of privacy principles, it will have undesirable economic consequences which the Opposition would have thought the Government would want to resist and certainly not encourage.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has other objections to the details of the new provisions. I will not go into them in any detail; I just mention them because I do not want it to be thought that the Opposition is simply concerned with this particular aspect of the legislation. We are opposed, as the people in the corporate sector I have described who have expressed their strong views are opposed, to the disclosure required of significant volumes of business with particular parties. Regardless of whether or not the viability of a company depends on a relationship, it has to be disclosed. The test of what is a significant volume of business is ambiguous. It could be anti-competitive, as could another requirement-namely, the disclosure of the separate contribution of the profit and loss of companies in which the disclosing company has a material interest. There are, as I have said, requirements to disclose the superannuation arrangements of directors and employees, and to give recent valuations of interest in land and buildings which can also contain significant ambiguities and to which widespread objections have been voiced.

The Opposition strongly prefers a different approach to these matters, as does the industry and the professional accounting bodies. We would prefer to see the development of the approved accounting standards which are already in place. That is the policy of the legislation and of the Ministerial Council. This can be backed where necessary by legislative action. We think that this new Schedule is an unhappy and unjustified return to the old technical approach and that a new and different approach, which has already been legislated for and which is operating successfully, as one can see from the recent report of the Accounting Standards Review Board, should be adopted for the present and the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government resists this motion for disallowance. There is a certain irony in Senator Durack moving it in the way in which he did, arguing that the matters dealt with in these regulations ought to be the subject of accounting standards rather than regulations because one of the characteristics of accounting standards is that they are not subject to any disallowance by the Parliament, only by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, with the legislative process having no role at all in determining the content of such standards. Senator Durack seems to want to abdicate completely parliamentary or governmental authority in relation to these things rather than accept the responsibility, as we all must, in a democratic parliamentary system to take policy responsibility for these matters of great moment. The new Schedule to the companies regulations has in fact evolved over a period of--
—What responsibility does Parliament exercise on your approach to these matters?

—A great deal. We are up here defending these particular measures in public and not hiding behind whatever it is that the business community wants to put up in its own interests without regard to the overriding public interest. It is proper that these matters be dealt with in forums of this kind and we are perfectly happy to explain and justify whatever policy decisions we take. This particular set of policy decisions has, as I have said, evolved over a period of almost four years. There is no question of its being sprung in any alarming or improper way upon the business community. The proposals were exposed for public comment on two occasions during that period right back in 1983 in the form of a National Companies and Securities Commission Green Paper and again in 1985-86 in the form of draft regulations. While it certainly cannot be denied that the new Schedule imposes a number of additional reporting obligations on some companies, this is largely a reflection of the changes in overseas views-in the United Kingdom and the United States of America particularly-of what constitutes good reporting during the 15-year period in which the Australian requirements stood absolutely still.

SPEECH.PARA: But let us put the new requirements in perspective. The new Schedule introduces significantly reduced requirements for all exempt proprietary companies, which make up about 95 per cent of all Australian companies. In future, these companies will only have to prepare a profit and loss account and balance sheet and provide notes about commitments for expenditures, contingent liabilities and, where auditors have been appointed, auditors' remuneration. All of the remaining public companies and proprietary companies in which shares are owned by public companies or overseas corporations will have to provide the following additional information over and above their existing disclosure requirements; that is to say details of asset valuations where they are supported by guarantees, warranties or indemnities; particulars of payments to prescribed persons or prescribed superannuation funds and details of directors' remuneration. In addition, certain additional information has to be provided by listed companies, borrowing corporations and other large companies. The Ministerial Council has judiciously balanced this combination of exemptions and new requirements on the basis that the benefits flowing from the substantial reductions in disclosure requirements that apply to the exempt proprietary companies far outweigh the alleged disadvantages of bringing the disclosure requirements of the other categories of companies more closely into line with overseas requirements.

The Opposition has talked, particularly through the thundering and the Press release warfare conducted by the shadow Attorney-General, about the additional burdens that these requirements place on business, especially big business. I think it needs to be said that disallowance of these regulations in the way that the Opposition is now irresponsibly seeking would only serve to increase business costs and would result, certainly, in a great deal of confusion and uncertainty in the business community. Large parts of the business community have already invested considerable sums of money in gearing up for the new requirements. There is no possibility of the Accounting Standards Review Board substituting any alternative requirements in these areas in the sort of time frame we are talking about if an instant disallowance is put in place. More importantly, I guess, the smaller companies, allegedly the political constituency of this Opposition, are looking immensely forward to taking immediate advantage of these new requirements.

How does the Opposition propose to justify to those 95 per cent of companies in this community that will be largely removed from reporting requirements at all under this legislation that they have to suffer, that they have to continue the burden of paperwork just to prevent the other 5 per cent from allegedly suffering-the 5 per cent who are perfectly well able to look after themselves and have the procedures, the staff, the resources and the wherewithal to do just that? So much for the Opposition's alleged passionate adherence to the interests of the small business community. It is a sham and a charade, as it is so often with the Opposition's posturing on these matters.

As to the particular matters in the Schedule that have attracted comment or criticism, let me say only a word or two about the two issues of directors' remuneration and executive remuneration which attract the most passionate neurosis on the part of the Opposition. As far as executive remuneration is concerned, the Australian requirement is based squarely on the position of the United States of America, although the remuneration of individual officers does not have to be disclosed, as Senator Macklin pointed out by way of interjection, interrupting Senator Durack in mid-flight on that matter. So much for the privacy concerns that he was endeavouring to advance. As in the case of directors - -

TALK.START.PARA: —Can't you divide by five?

—If the honour- able senator thinks that is the way business works he is even more out of touch than I thought he was. I, and I am sure a lot of people in the business community, would be delighted to know that the number fives in the hierarchy are getting exactly the same return as the number ones and number twos. That aint the way the world works, as Senator Durack ought to know but manifestly does not. We will not be able to pick and choose on the basis of any ratio between the top five. The reality is that there are all sorts of individual arrangements for remuneration at that level. Simply having a total figure will do no more than give a general guide as to the way in which shareholders' funds are being utilised in the managerial area. The principle behind giving the shareholders that much access to information is quite clear. If they are to determine whether they are getting value for money out of senior executives employed on their behalf they need to know, at least in the general and limited terms that we are suggesting here, how much they are paying. As far as directors' remuneration is concerned, the principle is exactly the same. If the shareholders are going to be able to determine whether they get value for money they need to know how much they are paying. After all, they are employing the directors.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been an inference in a number of Opposition statements on this matter, particularly by Mr Spender-I think Senator Durack was too embarrassed to make the point today, but let me respond to it-to the effect that shareholders can already find out this sort of information. The reality is, however, that it is not a simple task for a shareholder to find 5 per cent of fellow shareholders in order to require a company to provide the information in question. Just to take one obvious example, what about the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd? Five per cent of issued shares in BHP is a total of 63 million shares and only the four largest shareholders hold that number. It would be virtually impossible for the average BHP shareholders to gather sufficient of their number to represent 5 per cent of the issued shares. The top 20 shareholders, those ranked twelfth to twentieth, in aggregate, do not between them hold 5 per cent of the issued shares in that corporation.

So the reality is that the existing procedures are manifestly inadequate to enable access to this kind of information. It is information which ought to be available to those with an interest in having it. Well managed companies and companies in respect of which the directors are doing their job in the interests of shareholders have manifestly nothing whatsoever to fear from this kind of scrutiny. It is in line with the kind of disclosure requirements that have become very much the norm in other comparable parts of the world and there is no basis whatsoever for these regulations to be thus disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with a regulation that emanates from the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities. I do not want to rehearse today the types of problems that we have had in previous debates when either legislation or regulations have emanated from that body. The difficulties have been apparent of this chamber's dealing with material that comes from that body. It is sufficient to say that State governments of Labor, Liberal and National Party persuasion are all agreed on this item. That in itself seems to be a singularly extraordinary event in Australia's political history. Most people realise that the differences between States in Australia are far greater than between countries in most parts of the rest of the world. Therefore, when all State governments and the Federal Government agree on a set of guidelines or on amendments to the principal legislation, it is very difficult to deal with that in the way that we deal with material that is merely a policy decision of the current Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Various items were raised in the last debate that we had on this matter. The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who is currently at the table, undertook to look at the types of procedures that were being used, particularly with regard to amendments to the principal legislation. We hope that that is being fulfilled. With regard to the points that Senator Durack raised, the arguments as he presented them are really not sufficient to overcome that extraordinary agreement of all State governments and the Federal Government, involving all parties, to promote this regulation.

The accountancy items that Senator Durack wished to make the focus of the disallowance are certainly of a highly technical nature. I do not propose to canvass any further points other than the ones raised by the Minister on that item. It seems to me that the ability to replace these with other items is probably not there. I suggest that the fact that we have State and Commonwealth agreement to these precludes, certainly in the next two or three years, the ability to agree on a completely different set of accounting principles. Surely, the mere political logic of the operation is that we should stay with these or else we will not have anything. Hence, we would be most loth, in the absence of extremely compelling arguments, to accept the proposition that we should do away with this set.

The other item that Senator Durack raised related to the remuneration of directors and executives. The Minister raised points, particularly with regard to exempt proprietary companies. I think the Minister said that up to 95 per cent-I am not sure and would use the more conservative figure of 90 per cent at least-of companies in Australia are exempt proprietary companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Due to the increase in business activity under this Government. You haven't kept up with it.

—We have an updated figure from the Minister. But at least 90 per cent of those small businesses, those exempt proprietary companies-in other words those ones in which generally the entire operation is run by a husband and wife or a family, such as a corner store; in other words, the vast bulk of our companies-will have significant reductions in their accounting necessities. That is extremely important. Indeed, it is something that small business has been asking for over a long period. To overthrow this at this time does not seem to be terribly sane politics for the Opposition or for anybody in Australia, quite frankly, given the current push of small business in the political world. I am not quite sure why the Opposition has decided to take on the small business sector in this way and suggest that accounting and reporting procedures should be increased when in fact the Government has moved to lessen them significantly.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to directors of big business, it is legitimate that the fees and other emoluments paid to those directors be available to the shareholders of the non-exempt proprietary companies. Basically, we are talking about public companies. It seems that a listing on the stock market already brings with it a certain disclosure. This merely follows that trend of disclosure and is a disclosure that the shareholders are well entitled to. The fees of directors are an expenditure of a company. We want to know what they are receiving. Most other major groupings in society already have their incomes disclosed. It does not seem to me to be a major intrusion.

In terms of executives, as I pointed out by way of interjection, it does not relate to a particular executive but to the aggregate emolument of the top five executives. It is interesting to look at the Thatcher approach to this in the Companies Act in Britain in 1985. Section 22 (1) relating to emoluments to directors states that there shall be shown the aggregate amount of the directors' emoluments. In other words, Britain has not gone for the particularisation of directors' emoluments. But it is different for executives. The point is often raised in the media about head-hunting and picking off people. That would be much more difficult under the Australian regulation. With figures given for the top five, it is difficult to pinpoint precisely what people are receiving. Therefore, the head-hunting argument really does not hold up. But in the British experience it certainly does. Although on first reading it may appear similar to Australia's, it certainly is not in practice. Section 35 (1) states:

There shall be shown by reference to each pair of adjacent points on a scale whereon the lowest point is #30,000 and the succeeding ones are successive integral multiples of #5,000 beginning with that in the case of which the multiplier is 7-
in other words, #35,000-
The number (if any) of persons in the company's employment whose several emoluments exceeded the lower point but did not exceed the higher.

That must be one of the most convoluted bits of drafting I have seen in a long time. Basically, it means that one starts off at #30,000. One takes #5,000 and works out how many people fall within #30,000 and #35,000, between #35,000 and #40,000 and between #45,000 and #50,000. Of course, in practice what happens is that, while at the bottom scale there may be a number of people, say, four or five, as one reaches the higher scales there will be the staggering number of one. So one could certainly work out what the highest executive is being paid and one could probably work out pretty closely what the two deputies will be paid, and even have a fair stab at what the next general manager level will be paid. So under the British Thatcher Administration, of which I thought the Opposition was quite enamoured, executives' emoluments are laid out in a very bare fashion. This regulation does not do that to anywhere near the same extent.

Alternatively, the British method does make it much more difficult to get at the directors' fees. But it seems to me that the Australian approach of the identification of the individual directors is much more important than the identification of the executives' fees. After all, the executives are all employees of the companies. The directors are the ones directing the public policies of the companies. Particularly in our major public companies, there is a very strong national interest in knowing what emoluments those people are getting in return for the directions they are providing for those companies. Hence I indicate that we will not support the Opposition's disallowance motion on this, basically on the lines that the regulation emanates from the Ministerial Council and as such has been agreed by all State governments and the Federal Government, that is, by Liberal Party governments, National Party governments and Labor Party governments. On that basis it seems that we do not have any option. This is the only game in town and hence it should be supported.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Durack's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1986-87[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1986-87APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1986-87]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 November, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was interrupted last night I was explaining how the Budget of the Government could be called the Budget of a thousand cuts, and that these cuts have been made in most inappropriate places. I was moving on to explain the effects of these cuts on Telecom Australia. The Government decided to remove from Telecom's budget an extra $98m. This seemed to be part of the phoney exercise to produce a deficit of around $3,500m rather than the more average one of 33 per cent of the gross national product, which would have been around $4.6m. The only reason for the Government's doing this can be a response to the international money markets and the large corporations rather than showing any concern for the people of Australia, and particularly the poorer people.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the decisions the Government has taken have involved cuts in budgets of departments which make profits. Telecom is an organisation which makes a profit and which could, if properly managed in the area, give an enormous boost to our telecommunications industry. We are now in the forefront of fibre optics research in the world. Billion dollar markets are available for products such as fibre optics products. We have the ability to chase these markets and we have the ability to follow them through, provided that Telecom, like the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, gives the boost by making these products in our domestic market. The Government seems to be squeezing these organisations of research and development funds. The Ergas report, `Telecommunications and the Australian Economy', drew attention to this neglect. It pointed out the need for increases in investment in real terms of the order of 10 to 15 per cent per annum for several years in order for us to establish ourselves in this industry. We cannot afford not to establish ourselves in this industry because the balance of payment costs for the country will be very great if we have to buy in all our telecommunications needs.

I believe that this type of policy has come from pressure from the puppet-masters in the Treasury. The Government must learn to resist listening to these people in the way in which it is doing, just following through the type of program that is set out for it by Treasury along American-based monetarist lines. The Government must also think clearly about what departments can make money for it and what departments do not make money. Everything seems to be treated as a cost, but in fact the Department of Communications actually brings in more money that it spends. We should be expanding such areas. I shall return to that point later.

No one will be fooled by the attempt by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) to justify the Commonwealth's abdication of its role in relation to English as a second language. No one is taken in by the `administrative charge' euphemism for the reintroduction of tertiary fees. I should like to look a little more closely at what has been happening. While the right hand has been throttling English as a second language, multicultural education, and computer education programs, the left hand-in the form of the Minister for Education-has been calling for a national target of 65 per cent of students to complete year 12 at the start of 1990. Senator Ryan has also called for an upgrading of science education. I believe that these calls are completely empty gestures, given the determination of the various people in Cabinet who seem to be set on following a Thatcherite path to a brave new world. I believe that most Australians can understand how the Government's antics are robbing Australia of a reasonably rosy future because of completely short term measures and views.

That is exactly the position. I point out to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) that there is strong community protest over this latest round of unwarranted and discriminatory cutbacks. On Budget night I was able to liken the whole process to someone falling asleep on a giant ant-hill. The individual stings would hurt but would not be fatal, yet the overall effect may be total collapse and death. That is exactly the type of effect of this Budget. That is certainly where we are heading while the Government remains captive to the various corporate interests which see Australia purely as a mineral and agricultural producer ripe for gross exploitation.

In that contest, I deplore the decision to withdraw our Peruvian representation. It is an outrage and a snub which has not gone unnoticed, I believe, in Latin America. I notice that Senator Gareth Evans is leaving the chamber on that point. I think that it is a serious point for us to note that the Peruvian government is one of the governments that have made a strong stand on moving towards a new world economic order, and we should be supporting it rather than cutting our support in that area. It seems that the present Australian Government is afraid of working towards a strong and independent Australia; it seems to be shrinking away from the process of working towards a new world economic order. I believe that in the Whitlam time this vision would have meant that that we would not have agreed to removing the Peruvian representation.

However, as things stand, quite a few members of the dominant minority faction within the Government seem to spend much of their time working out ways of implementing the current Opposition policy. This is a real contradiction in politics at present. There is very little to distinguish between the policy of the right of the Labor Party and the Liberal Party's policy. That is probably because policy is completely set down by Treasury. We have had several decades in pursuit of an egalitarian society, and the whole operation of the present Government seems to be undoing that process. The sad thing is that it is a government that has a Labor label on it. A prime example is the reintroduction of tertiary fees under the euphemism of an administrative charge. I do not believe that this fools anyone, and the Government should realise that. It is a first step towards a massive fee structure that will make education the preserve of the wealthy and speed our slide into the state of an undeveloped country, a banana republic.

The overseas student charge has been a forerunner for this little exercise. Its rapid escalation shows that once the Treasury gets its teeth into something, it will continue nibbling away until eventually the structure falls apart. What needs to be remembered is that we no longer have the former safety net of the bonded teacher scholarship to enable those with poorer backgrounds to scrape their way through college or university. Once we start actively to discourage post-graduate students, we can make preparation for the vassal status which will eventually fall upon us in this world-a colony of people who will just be working on the fringes, digging holes in the ground to produce minerals for other people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must be joking.

—It is estimated, Senator Grimes, that the value of research done free of charge by post-graduate students is worth between $10m and $25m per year to Australia. For that reason the report of the Goldring Committee of Review of Private Overseas Student Policy recommended against charging fees to post-graduate students. It is estimated that about 20 per cent of these students will withdraw if the $250 fee is imposed. For a total apparent yield of a few million dollars, in fact the Government stands to make a loss of about the same amount by imposing this fee on post-graduate students. It just does not make economic sense-any more than the Australian Broadcasting Corporation-Special Broadcasting Service merger makes any type of sense.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, the overseas student visa fee for post-graduate students of about $4,500 per year will leave those students only $2,500 per year on which to live. I doubt whether any honourable senator would be prepared to live under those conditions. Yet these people are contributing to research to the value of $25,000 each per year, and for the most part this is in technological and scientific fields, in which they may represent up to 35 per cent of the total of post-graduate students. They are making a major contribution to the development of our industrial effort, and I believe that we should recognise and recognise that it is totally and blatantly unreasonable to add insult to injury by increasing the fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know the definition of the word `populist'? You are a perfect example.

—Yes; I believe in supporting people; that is what matters to me. The Government stands to lose $18,000 per overseas student per year by imposing this unjust visa fee on students. These people should be recognised as benefactors for the future technological success of Australia. Surveys at Adelaide University and the University of New South Wales show that about two-thirds of students will have difficulty in paying the $250 fee. We can imagine what will happen if they have to find $2,500 if the Government raises the fees to about 25 per cent of the cost per student, which one can see, possibly, in the offing. I hope that I am wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the sort of rubbish that comes from a government that asks us to believe that it is determined to lift participation rates and to give us proper skills for the future. Perhaps some Cabinet Minister can tell me whether the Government thinks that it is easier to preside over a banana republic than over a trained and well informed community. Dr Anderson of the Australian National University, whose work on the effects of the abolition of tertiary fees has been gravely misrepresented in this place, made some very cogent comments which were reported in the Age of 19 March 1985. He said that his most recent evidence showed that, after decades without change, at the end of the 1970s there had been a noticeable shift towards equality among the groups of school leavers entering higher education. He went on to say:

. . . in the USA evidence is emerging of a sharp regression in participation due to sharp rises in tuition fees following the Reagan Administration's cuts in federal funding to universities and colleges.

Is this really the sort of society that the majority in the Australian Labor Party wants to head towards? Is this the type of society the Labor Party wants, so shortly after Caucus rejected the introduction of tertiary fees? It is an amazing turnaround on a scale similar to that of the outrageous decision to resume sales of uranium to France-just after the platform was reaffirmed at a carefully stage-managed conference in Hobart. The Labor Party no longer seems capable of standing up for what is right. That is why so many former supporters are deserting it each day and joining up with organisations that still have a vestige of integrity. The University of Queensland Union summed it up quite adroitly when it said:
Labor promised participation and equity. It would appear that participation is restricted to the wealthy and equity exists only in an international banker's trust.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, for heaven's sake!
—It is in fact, Senator Grimes, the golden rule: Those who have the gold, rule.
—What is equitable about giving the sons and daughters of wealthy people free tuition in that way? Tell us what is equitable about that. You are a populist of the worst type.

—It is quite equitable to make certain that everybody can get in there. It may make little difference to the rich people-and the Government is already collecting a fair amount in tax from those people. Certainly it is not doing very much about collecting tax from some people.

—Don't tell me! That is the worst form of populism I have ever heard in this place. Not even the most conservative person over there would put that argument. That is the worst form of populism I have ever heard.
—I would indeed like to take issue with this. It is obvious that--
—He is putting our lights out.

—Even the lights are going out under this Government. I would like to examine some of the reasons given by the Government for its abandonment of traditional Labor concern for the underdog-because it really is the underdog who is suffering. The Government might be shooting at the children of the rich, but really the people it is hitting are the poor in this country, the people whom the Government is not giving an opportunity to get an education. That is the real problem. In the first case, I believe the Government has been totally overrun by the terms of trade which Australia faces. It has been left with the problem of a very large deficit. It is panicking and is quite unable to see that the very rich corporations and overseas organisations are exploiting Australia and making the most out of this situation while ordinary Australians cannot escape the effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has not delivered to the people of Australia a sensible program. In the communications area, it has been kowtowing to the large media consortia with its aggregation program. There is also the shenanigans over broadcasting policy and the Government's failure to take decisive action against those responsible for the inept handling by the Department of Communications of the expansion of services throughout Australia. It is also a fact that that Department is hopelessly underresourced in engineering staff, and has been so over the period since the big shift from Melbourne. I believe that the Government should take very firm action against the policy bunglers in this Department, who seem to have a client mentality of serving just the large networks and their representatives, the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations and the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, rather than taking any notice of the public interest as they are employed to do. The record on the extension of radio and television services to regional Australia is shameful. It continues to deplete the Government's revenue while failing to deliver real choice to listeners and viewers.

The Government has also missed many opportunities to reverse our reliance on agricultural and mineral exports by moving into more value added exports. In some ways it has gone backwards through its assistance to foreign interests, allowing them to pick off Australian producers one by one, or to pick off our choicest manufacturing concerns, reinforcing the branch plant mentality through encouraging a corporate raider boom. As I pointed out earlier, the Government has also hampered the investment activities of Telecom Australia and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission through its demands for extra repayments and its threats to allow the Treasury and the Department of Finance to intrude continually into their activities.

I want to take an even more fundamental case because, although it is small and perhaps relatively unnoticed it demonstrates the `New Right-is' which has infected the Hawke Government. The Government is in fact becoming the New Right itself. It certainly bodes ill for our future, just as it demonstrates why the executives of multinational companies regard this Administration as a bit of a joke. The Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) often tells us just how good we are at conceiving ideas and even patenting something as a result-but that it all falls down when we try to develop these ideas into products or services. With that in mind, I want to consider the Patents, Trade Marks and Designs Office, with which I had an illuminating encounter in Estimates Committee A. In the 1984-85 Budget, staffing for the Technical Information Branch within the Office was increased from five to 16, and a little extra money was set aside for its travel expenses. The explanatory notes waxed lyrical on how this was going to help the transfer of technology. I quote from it:

An extensive promotional program has been developed to encourage the business, academic and government sectors to avail themselves of this information and to educate the clientele on the range of information which is available and the most effective methods to access it.
The effective implementation and promotion of this government initiative has the potential to generate an increase in the revenue earned by the Patent Office.

That was indeed a very enthusiastic buildup-and quite rightly so. After all, overseas countries respected for their ability to export high technology products have long fuelled the process of industrial innovation with the strategic dissemination of technical information. That is a very good reason for us to get involved also. In fact, the Australian Science and Technology Council report on Mechanisms for Technology Transfer into Australia, released earlier this year, took up this point with great gusto. It took great pleasure in describing the operations of the Japanese Information Centre for Science and Technology. That body acts as a central clearing house for technical information generated within Japan or obtained elsewhere. It receives the equivalent of $25m from government sources each year and generates $19m more from subscriptions and service fees. It has an on-line information retrieval network collected over 10 years, and this database can be accessed from terminals right around Japan. It is in great demand because it is kept at the cutting edge of latest developments. Our Government seems to be intent on closing all of this down. One would have thought that, with that build-up, the technology transfer unit would have been kept. No, the Government has closed it down at this stage. These are just some of the examples which I will be expanding on and asking a few questions about during the Committee stage consideration of this most disappointing Budget. I believe that it is really a Budget of no hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bills, of course, provide us with the opportunity to take stock of this Government's policies as expressed in the 1986 Federal Budget and the impact that they are having on the Australian community. What concerns me most of all is that families are yet again the big losers under this Government. I very rarely find myself in agreement with anything much that the Australian Democrats say, but I can find myself to a degree in agreement with what Senator Vigor has said: Invariably we now find that it is the lower income earners of the Australian community who are suffering most. We are continually told that tax cuts, deferred of course in part until 1 December and not beginning in full until 1 July 1987, will restore incentive and redress the costs now imposed by the fringe benefits tax, increased sales tax and fuel excise and, of course, the freezing of benefits to families, but the fact is that families will still be worse off at the end of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting that soon after the August Budget Mr George Campbell of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union and Mr Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association agreed that the average wage earner would be worse off by around $15 a week, a figure that would fall only to $12.40 when the tax rates fell in December. What is even more interesting is to compare the amount of tax paid by a person of average weekly earnings in March 1983 when this Hawke Government came into power with what he is paying today, and what he will pay in July next year when the tax cuts are fully in force. The marginal rate has risen from 30 per cent to 46 per cent today and will still be at 40 per cent next year. Fiscal drag, that old ally of big taxing governments, is far more effective than a formal rise in the tax rate. The same taxpayer in 1983 paid nearly 23 per cent of his total income in tax, a figure that now stands at 26 per cent and in July of next year will amount to 24.5 per cent of pay as you earn earnings. This means that he is 1.6 per cent worse off after the tax cuts compared to when this Government took office. A family supported by a single income of average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse would have paid 17.5 per cent of its income in tax in March 1983. Today the same family pays 21.6 per cent and next year will pay 20.5 per cent, so it is going to be significantly worse off by a full 3 per cent of income.

By late next year the dependent spouse rebate will have declined 27 per cent since November 1982, and the rebate that in 1951 would have equalled 47 per cent of average weekly earnings for a family with five children now amounts to 1 per cent of earnings. While the introduction of the family allowance makes such a comparison probably of limited value, we should remember that the value of the family allowance has fallen by up to 50 per cent in 10 years since its introduction. The larger the family, the more likely it is to be disadvantaged under this Australian Labor Party Government, especially when we realise that 74 per cent of families with more than six children have incomes below $20,000. It is difficult enough for a family with one child to live on $20,000, but 74 per cent with more than six have incomes below $20,000. The larger the family obviously the more disadvantaged it is.

It is a good illustration of the Hawke Government's attitude to such families that the family allowance is the one area of social security spending to see a sharp reduction. Expenditure is down by $172m, 11 per cent, while the supporting parents' benefit rises by $123m, nearly 10 per cent. This is just a further illustration of how this Government provides a greater incentive for marriage break-up than for families to stay intact, and the intact families of Australia are increasingly weighed down by the taxation of this ALP Government; and this Government does not care. We need to be more conscious of the fact that a couple with one child requires 30 per cent more income to retain the same living standard as a couple without any children. It is also worth considering that a family income of $39,000, the cut-off for the family allowance for children over 16, is not so massive if the family is a large one. Once again, $39,000 per year in this day and age does not go very far with a large family.

These facts do not necessarily mean that the family allowance should be massively increased. What they do mean to the Liberal Party is that the overall tax burden of the Australian family simply must be reduced as a matter of high priority and as a matter of survival for these families. Family income splitting remains a fair and obvious solution to assist the massive numbers of families dependent on one income or maybe on one and a half incomes, and that is about the only solution that can be offered in a fair and equitable way to encourage families to have children and to enable them to survive with children. Families will get no long term benefit from the vaunted tax cuts, as I have illustrated, because more taxpayers on average incomes drift into higher tax brackets.

This Budget is not going to assist Australian families indirectly by restoring sound economic management because it is becoming an absolute joke now. The Euromoney magazine which saw fit to give the Treasurer (Mr Keating) his prized accolade a few years back is the same magazine now, of course, which is giving him the prize as runner-up to the most disastrous economic manager. I am glad that the magazine has seen the light of day. In effect, it has only confirmed, of course, what small business and the taxpayers of Australia have generally been saying for months and months. Taxpayers in this country are not being bluffed and blinded by the rhetoric of this Treasurer saying that the Government is fighting for the welfare of the lower income families.
