The point must be driven home that the Budget was not an exercise in long term responsibility and truly courageous spending cuts, because the reduction of the deficit by $2.2 billion is not such a remarkable achievement when we look at the fact that $1.5 billion has been raised through increased taxation, creating that heavier burden on each and every person, and a further $0.6 billion has helped balance the books through the gain in currency trading of the Reserve Bank of Australia.

As I have said before, so much expenditure reduction lies in deferments in preference to really biting the bullet and tackling the problems at their source. Government services may well be reduced, but the size of government remains. Also, the size of government in terms of employment and staffing is up by 0.3 per cent and salaries will increase by 6 per cent. Those Australian breadwinners who are working one and a half days of the average 40-hour week just to pay direct and indirect taxes would have every right to query this ALP Government's spending priorities, because money is still being found by this Government to fund such things as the Constitutional Commission, which the Australian people never asked for and which was established to serve the ideological ends of the ALP factions determined, quite frankly, to save us from ourselves through a new Constitution. Money will also still be available, and is still available, for political advocacy groups utilising taxes, or PAGUTS, such as the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, which is 99 per cent funded by the Federal Government. This organisation has benefited from a 300 per cent increase since the Australian Labor Party came to office. Such groups are characterised, as we all know, by a left wing bias and a comparatively small number of activist members who are highly unrepresentative of the general community. The general community is getting a little fed up, sick and tired of seeing money being dished out to the left wing biased groups at the expense of relief for ordinary taxpayers.

The Budget maintains Australia Council funding in real terms; so I suppose we can look forward to more of our taxes going to support the Sydney Gay Mardi Gras Association and to trade unions for crude political propaganda masquerading as community arts. It is worth remembering that in Western Australia alone the trade unions have so far creamed off $200,000 in this way for community arts. This Budget will not halt the process whereby the Hawke Government buys off the extreme Left with our money. What makes me really angry is the fact that in this same Budget the funding for marriage guidance organisations is frozen and therefore reduced in real terms. This has forced the Marriage Guidance Council in Western Australia in particular to close its country services. To me that is a real tragedy. These people are fighting very hard to keep families together, yet this Government sees fit to cut their funding, to split people up and not give them any assistance whatsoever. Voluntary organisations who fight to keep families together, with the resultant enormous savings to social security, should get higher rather than lower priority. They are getting the raw end of the deal compared with the fringe activists and the trade union militants when it comes to distributing the tax dollar taken, of course, from Australian families.

We should not forget that $500,000 is to be found for refurbishing the Sydney residence of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at Kirribilli, which already has a running cost of $12,000 a week. A further half a million dollars of taxpayers' money is being usurped by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to make the Prime Minister's life a little more comfortable in Sydney. There are many families in Australia who are not leading a comfortable life at all, yet this Government is providing a more comfortable life for the Prime Minister. Such are the spending priorities of this ALP Government.

Health expenditure priorities are an essential feature of the Budget, and I now turn to the direction this Government is taking the health of our nation and, of course, the price of that direction. Australia continues to suffer through this Government's misplaced belief in better health through systems analysis. Somehow the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) believes that if he can find the right mix of tax dollars and physical resources he can give us the ideal socialist health system. In most practical terms what we are being offered in theory is our overall health care at greater cost because this Government wants to preserve sacred cows and ignore reality. As I said previously on the Loans Bill, this ALP Treasurer has the gall to say in the Budget Speech that the Medicare levy should be increased `so that Medicare is self-financing'. The simple arithmetic of this situation contained within the same Budget Papers makes an absolute mockery of that statement. Therefore what we are looking at is a supposedly self-financing health system that will consume the equivalent of a 2.8 per cent levy on personal income to meet its costs. We should also remember that on numerous occasions the Minister has repeatedly said that there would be no increase in the Medicare levy. Obviously the Treasurer thought otherwise and he has increased the Medicare levy and proved yet again that what is promised and what one gets are two entirely different things. It just adds more and more and more to the list of broken promises that this Government made prior to the last election.
The Minister for Health, Dr-non-medical-Blewett, has also had the gall to say such absurd things as:
The Government is concerned to ensure that any changes should be made in the fairest possible way.
He also said:
. . . an overall package of measures within the health area which achieves restraint and equity.
But the best of all was when he said that the Government would:
. . . preserve its commitment to a universal health insurance scheme based on the principles of equity, simplicity and cost efficiency.

I put it to the Senate that we have none of those things. There is no cost efficiency, no equity and absolutely no simplicity. While the Minister for Health pursues a policy of non-interference with bulk billing, when we see figures released this week that more than 50 per cent of doctors are now bulk billing, he employs the techniques of a systems analyst to reduce hospital costs. His solution is simplicity itself: Limit public hospital benefits to a 2.9 per cent increase for 1986-87 and let the hospital system cope with the consequences. Like a First World War general, this socialist Minister seems to regard the lengthening hospital queues as part of the attrition process.

The Minister has also said that the continuation of bulk billing overwhelmingly works to the benefit of pensioners and the disadvantaged. Of course what he failed to add was that it overwhelmingly works to the benefit of the dishonest as well. No longer can pensioners and the disadvantaged be assured of a hospital bed when they need it, with the greater demand and lesser funding for public hospitals. How can that be classified as a system that `overwhelmingly works'? People are queueing up and they are not getting treated when they need it. The classic example in my State of Western Australia was brought to light on 5 August when it was reported in the West Australian newspaper that at the end of May, 3,450 patients were awaiting elective surgery at Royal Perth Hospital. Two months earlier the waiting list was only 3,000, with a further 1,400 awaiting surgery at Perth's other major teaching hospital, the Queen Elizabeth Medical Centre. According to a Royal Perth Hospital submission, heart patients are waiting up to 12 weeks and those patients with problems such as ear, nose and throat problems could be waiting anything up to two years. If that is a system that is `overwhelmingly working well, fairly and simply' then I would query it very genuinely.

Only 700 of the 4,400 on the surgery waiting list in March needed plastic surgery. That is always the argument of this socialist Minister-that people are going for elective surgery to have themselves dollied up and that is why the queues are so long. Only 700 of those 4,400 are waiting for that type of surgery. All the others had conditions which, if not life threatening, meant real discomfort. I wish that it meant so much discomfort to the Minister that he would do something about smartening up the health system in this country. We are treading the same path as that of the British national health service where people do not die of complaints, they die with complaints. That in itself is a tragedy. Of course, the true story is told of a national health service hospital administrator who wanted to place the bed of an incontinent patient under a roof leak as it would cause the patient no extra discomfort and would save on repairs. That is exactly where the policies of this Government are taking us.

The public hospitals are also becoming increasingly more concerned about their accreditation as teaching hospitals and so well they might because they are not getting the mix they used to get. This is simply not hearsay. They know that they are running real risks of accreditation because it is based on that mix that the doctors and nurses of tomorrow are trained. If they do not get that mix how can the doctors and the nurses of tomorrow be sure that they are getting the broad coverage they need? So what light can prospective patients see at the end of the tunnel if these doctors and nurses are not getting the training that will provide a wide service.

Under the guise of cost cutting the health Budget has savaged the private sector for essentially ideological reasons that will have the inevitable effect of forcing more Australians into the public health sector and adding to the hospital queues. We cannot have longer queues than we already have. We see in this Budget an incentive being created for people to move out of private health insurance because of the additional costs of that insurance. We must remember that people are already paying twice for health insurance. They have to pay the Government's wretched Medicare levy and now, in a full year, they will have to pay an extra $286 if they choose to take out private health insurance. That is not a small amount to lower and middle income earners. A full year's saving of $129m through the abolition of the private hospital bed day subsidy is likely to add $1.50 each week to private health insurance. So those families can be expecting to pay that extra $286 a year plus an increased Medicare levy. What is this going to do? The Minister for Health has said that private health insurance increases should be moderate. I put it to the Senate that $286 a year is not moderate. Some families simply will not be able to meet these additional costs. They will discontinue their private health insurance and will then be reliant on an already overworked public health system.

The other effect of this measure is that people will occupy public hospital beds at a cost to the Government of $280 a day, as opposed to the previous amount of $40 a day in a private hospital. Is it sound economic management to have a cost of $40 a day skyrocket to such an extent? That is typical of the type of economy practices in the health field undertaken by this socialist Government that is now claiming to have saved, or supposedly is trying to save, taxpayers' dollars. The sad aspect is that many simply cannot afford private health insurance, and this extra cost invariably will impinge on the aged. The aged in this country are getting worse and worse treatment from this Government, and it is the families of the aged, who are already pressed to the limit, who will be forced to find money to put their aged relatives into private hospitals and pay more now than they ever have before. Should we as a country be placing that type of strain on families? So the impact of this Budget will be more severely felt not by the financially well off but by those most in need.

Since the last Liberal Budget in 1982, total health spending has risen by over 100 per cent-from a grand total of $3,425m to $7,306m. Health spending has risen from 7.2 per cent to 9.8 per cent of Budget outlays. But it can hardly be argued that as a result of that greater expenditure people are getting a better deal. They are getting a far worse deal; they are getting far less service for their tax dollar. Those who pay twice for health care, who have private health insurance and who actually lessen the burden on the public health system, are clearly regarded with disfavour by a Labor government that has no concern whatsoever for those who want to provide for themselves. We should be creating incentive for people to provide for themselves; we should not be creating the disincentive. If people can provide for themselves, well and good, but let us not disadvantage them at the same time. If we are trying to reduce taxation, we should let people provide for themselves.

I have raised this matter because I consider the Medicare farce is a perfect example of the general economic policy direction of this Government, and the candour of the Treasurer in admitting that Australia has become a banana republic, and all the rhetoric about sacrifices and national purpose have not been matched by bold decisions. We must create incentive for the individual, we must create incentive for private enterprise and we must create incentive for people to look after themselves, but we must not tax them to death at the same time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1986-87, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1986-87. The Appropriation Bills collectively are designed to give effect to the Budget statements drawn up by the Federal Treasurer, Mr Keating, and delivered by him in the other place on 19 August this year. The Budget presented by the Treasurer has received overwhelming public acceptance by commentators in the media, by industrialists and by the trade union movement. That is not to say that some sections of the community-including indeed, some sections of the media, business and the trade union movement-have not voiced some criticisms of the Budget. However, practically all sectors of the community recognise that Australia is facing difficult economic times. Those difficult circumstances have forced our Government to take some tough budgetary decisions- decisions which largely have been forced upon it by the dictates of overseas money market zealots who judge the policies of governments such as ours by their own dry monetary standards. Some of the overseas money market mandarins have had the gall to offer advice to Australia on internal policies such as industrial relations- advice which would cause and has caused industrial havoc in this country; advice which will not prove in the long term to be beneficial to this country or its people. If as a result of our continued colonial cultural cringe we scramble to implement the dry monetary policies of those overseas mandarins, we could be facing diabolical problems within a few years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, as I have said, was faced with tough decisions. We had the problem, as all governments before us have had, of attempting to balance the Budget. In doing so we were forced to make many unpopular decisions in order to reduce the deficit-a deficit we inherited from the previous Government, a deficit we have worked hard for nearly four years to ease in order to rectify the tragic circumstances in which the Fraser regime left this country. We have grave problems not the least because of the international terms of trade having moved against us, something that we were not able to predict, particularly in the area of our two major export sectors, agricultural products and minerals. Falling world prices for these commodities have had a most unfortunate effect on our short term trade prospects. The devaluation of the dollar has assisted, and has presented an opportunity for exporters and manufacturers within Australia to compete on more favourable terms with imported items. Although we now have that opportunity it is unfortunate that not too many of those involved in enterprising management in Australia, particularly in the manufacturing sector, are taking full advantage.

In the light of the current circumstances we require responsible, reasoned responses from all sectors of the Australian community. We have witnessed, and are witnessing, the political sacrifices this Government has made in order to reduce the deficit. Similarly, we have witnessed continued restraint on the part of the vast majority of the trade union movement in Australia, a restraint which is demonstrated by the profitability of many companies. Many sections of the private sector have demonstrated a willingness to co-operate in the challenges which face us in the struggle to retain overseas markets and to guarantee deliveries to overseas nations. The vast majority of people have demonstrated a willingness to work for Australia's economic future, both in the short term and, more importantly, in the longer term. There are always exceptions to any rule.

Where are the people who have a decided responsibility to ensure that we, in government, do our job? Where do members of the Opposition stand? I am afraid that when one examines their role one sees that they do not measure up very well at all. I refer back to my own State and, indeed, the State from which the previous speaker, Senator Knowles, comes. She is a senator from Western Australia. In my own State very recently there was an amazing incident in which a State member of parliament, one Mr Ross Lightfoot, a Liberal member of the Legislative Assembly for Murchison-Eyre, wrote an impassioned plea to senior figures in the United States of America Government asking that positive damage be done to Australia's overseas wheat sales as that was the quickest way to bring down the Government. There was no interest in the economy and no interest in its people, just mere political expediency. Lightfoot was subsequently chastised by the Western Australian Parliament for that particular example of Liberal patriotism. But what has the Liberal Party done to him? We will wait and wait. Perhaps when we get a change of leadership in Western Australia we will see some action. But that is only being parochial in regard to my own State. I can be accused of that and I have no problems with being accused of that.

What is happening at the national level? We can look at the treasurer of the Liberal Party, a Mr John Elliott of Elders IXL Ltd, of Fosters lager fame. He has gone on record as saying: `Australia would be the last place you would want to invest in'. That was reported in the Australian Financial Review, the Age and many other newspapers in the middle of last month-on 17 October. There we have it. In an era when it is critical that all sections of Australian society work together to secure the economic future of this country, the true patriotism of the Opposition shows through. Members of the Opposition are committed to achieving power and ensuring that their friends can make a fast buck out of Australia. What is needed in this country at this time is consistency of supply. We have the spectre of the New Right attempting to impose its industrial panaceas unilaterally on the workers of Robe River in Western Australia. I will give some more detail at a later time in my contribution to the debate.

Let us examine the contribution the working people right across Australia have made to ensuring reliability of supply. In 1980, under the industrial relations expertise of the Fraser Government some 3.3 million working days were lost because of industrial disputation. Those days lost caused damage not only to industry but also to the people who were taking part in that industrial activity. They lost money as well. I think that point is often missed by media commentators. In 1981 it was even worse-4.2 million days were lost through industrial activity.

Let us compare that situation with what we have under the prices and incomes accord, the agreement between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the present Government. In 1984-85, 1.3 million days were lost through industrial activity. Under the accord we have seen industrial activity lessened to the degree of 65 per cent. That is happening in an era when real take-home pay has actually been reduced. At the same time, while real take-home pay has been reduced, profitability has recovered substantially from the depths that it reached under the previous Liberal Government led by Malcolm Fraser. Working people and the trade union movement have demonstrated that, when they are consulted and when they are given reasonable access to government on key issues, real, tangible sacrifices can be and are being made in the interests of Australia's future. Working people have always invested 100 per cent of their labour on behalf of this country. When we compare those actions with the actions of Ross Lightfoot, whom I have mentioned before, and John Elliott, we can really examine the loyalty of both sectors in the community to the future of this country.

In the last full financial year of the Fraser Government imports exceeded exports by $23 billion as opposed to $19.5 billion. The Labor Government, since taking office, has rectified this imbalance with the assistance of the working people of Australia and the active participation of the trade union movement, together with some of the more enlightened sections of the private sector. Thus, in the 1983, 1984 and 1985 financial years, Australia was able to show a surplus of exports over imports. However, the situation has changed and we are now faced with a number of external factors, not the least of which is the fact that world prices for a number of key export items are depressed on the world market. At such a critical time, what is the leadership of the Opposition doing? It is in attendance at meetings of the H. R. Nicholls Society and it is in attendance at H. R. Nicholls Society book launches. Leading figures of the H. R. Nicholls Society attend fashion parades. They are fund raisers for the Liberal Party.

The leadership of the Liberal Party has been very quick and very keen to align itself with the New Right. It is equally keen to defend its new heroes, people such as Charles Copeman, who came to fame very recently when he engaged in a cynical exercise to smash the trade union movement of this country at the Robe River plants in Pannawonica and Cape Lambert in Western Australia. Mr Copeman was perfectly willing to place Australian exports of iron ore-a crucial commodity in our export area-at risk through his actions and the actions of his company. The money that we, as a nation, earn from those exports is all at risk. For what purpose? In pursuit of narrow sectarian objectives with the claim that they want to free up the labour market and the industrial legal structures which have been in force since Federation.

However, many people are seeing through the hidden agenda and seeing what Copeman and Mr Howard are all about. They are not in pursuit of some fine point of industrial law. It merely comes down to a question of class greed, a philosophy that working people in Australia earn too much and that more of the cake should be channelled to the owners of capital. The sacrifice that working people have made over the years in terms of wage restraint has not been enough for the Copemans, the Hays or many other activists of the New Right in Australia. In fact, no amount of sacrifice by working people will satisfy the New Right. There is no way in the world that we can make any reasonable deals with people such as that.

The employer-initiated strife at the Peko- Wallsend installation at Robe River in Cape Lambert and Pannawonica is an example of what the current leadership of the Opposition would like to put in place as an industrial relations panacea. These panaceas might be attractive to some of the money market men in Wall Street, but they would assuredly be alarming to industrialists in overseas countries who have to operate in the real concrete world of production, as opposed to speculation, and have to depend on the steady supply of Australian raw materials. There are plenty of other sources of supply in the world at the moment. That is why the world price for iron ore and other items is currently so depressed. So Mr Copeman and, by implication, Mr Howard are quite happy to put our exports at risk. Because of them, Australian exports are of secondary importance to the freeing up of the industrial system in order to grab a bigger share of the cake for the owners of capital in Australia. The Old Right and the New Right will always have in common the greed of the greedy to have more.

Responsibility is what is required by all sections of the Australian community at this time. Many sections of society are answering the challenge that is demanded of them, but some honourable senators opposite must look more critically-indeed, they are doing so at this very moment-at the so-called leadership being displayed by the Opposition front bench. Johnnie Howard and the dries know as much about punk rock as they do about industrial relations. Ultimately, good industrial relations, among other things, will enable this country to overcome its trading difficulties. Reasonable people on the Opposition benches must bring their influence to bear to demand a leadership that is not dependent on the strident and decisive philosophy of the New Right. Australia needs the combined, co-operative efforts of all at this moment.

I commend Mr Steele Hall for having the guts to stand up and warn the Liberal Party of Australia to be wary that it does not end up on the same political desert island as the New Right is on. Mr Steele Hall found that some earlier remarks by Mr Neil Brown, the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, were encouraging a positive drift of perceptions that members of the Party were tied to the extremes of the Right. He said that he rejected that position because, if it were true, it would mean the demise of the Liberal Party as we have known it. Mr Steele Hall was speaking in early October. Since then he has received a thorough dressing down for his pains and Mr Howard and Mr Brown have continued the warm and moist relationship with the New Right and the Liberal Party has continued its slide to the extremes of the political spectrum-a slide which is causing enormous trauma at the moment because of the leadership difficulties. Members of the Liberal Party have no leadership. They are now in a position which makes the Party irrelevant because they could not hope to gain the confidence of large sections of the Australian community as a viable alternative to the present Government.

I said earlier that I wanted to refer to some matters relating to Peko-Wallsend and its operation at Robe River in the Pilbara of Western Australia. Events in the Pilbara have made headlines right across Australia. Only very recently a judgment was handed down by the West Australian Industrial Relations Commission. That judgment, which runs to 200-odd pages, makes some very interesting reading. I have some quotes from it that need to be placed on the record because I do not think they have been fairly or adequately publicised. All honourable senators would know that on 11 August this year, the company concerned decided to close its operations at both of the places I mentioned earlier and to sack 1,150 members of staff. The reason given by the company-I have the letter from the company but I will not quote it-was that the company could no longer exercise its managerial prerogatives to manage the operations because of an order handed down by another commissioner in the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

However, in the transcript of the hearing that led up to this decision we find some very interesting information. I wish to quote what the Operations Manager and Registered Manager for the port at Cape Lambert had to say. He advised the company that things were virtually out of control. I will quote just a small part of the actual transcipt where he states:

We really had plant running out there and we had people wandering around the site and we had no supervision and really under the Mines Regulations Act I saw that I had no way to turn other than to close that plant down and at least return the equipment to a safe condition.
The Chief Commissioner of the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission, Mr Collier, in presenting his findings, stated in part:

Under cross examination the witness said that the operation was safe until 2300 hours on 10th August 1986. Shift change advices commenced issuing on 5th August and the first shift change took place on 10th August at 2300 hours.
Mr Commissioner Collier, quoting the witness, stated further:
He considered that anarchy was on site and a supervisor could not expect reasonable orders to be obeyed. However, his information came from others because he was absent from the site at the time.
Let me quote again from what Mr Collier had to say before I wind up my contribution today:
I find that the situation at both the port-
that is, Cape Lambert-
and the mine-
Pannawonica-
which caused the closure of both operations could have been avoided if the respondent-
which is Robe River Iron Associates-

had exercised its prerogative to manage in a reasonable way. In its zeal to show the workforce that the days described earlier in these reasons were over the respondent either forgot or chose to ignore that it had an obligation to honour the arrangements that had been entered into with the workforce in the past and, pursuing an obstinate approach which precluded any discussion whatever with its workforce or their representatives on future relations, made decisions which produced inevitable and easily foreseen consequences. Its notice to all employees on 31st July . . . tore up agreements which it had negotiated under its own joint consultation policy over the years with its workforce. Thus its own actions led to the chaos which caused the closure of the operations and I find that the termination of the services of its workforce in the circumstances to be quite unfair.

I think the quotations that I have just gone through clearly show that the blame for the closure of the Robe River plant in Western Australia was the fault of the management. It was done clearly to establish a new vogue in Australia's industrial relations-all power to management and nothing to the work force. If this trend continues, Australia will be in a very sorry state in a very short time.

What is the response of the trade union movement? I had the honour of being in attendance at a Mining Unions Association meeting in Port Hedland on Monday last week and at a meeting of the Western Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council on the Tuesday and Wednesday. At the meeting on Monday the Mining Unions Association developed and later put forward a proposal to the tripartite body at the Consultative Council meeting on the Wednesday. I would like to read very quickly that proposal into the record to show what responsibility is on the side of the trade union movement. The document is headed `M.U.A. Proposal on Improved Efficiency and Productivity`, and there are about seven points in it. It states:
A. The M.U.A. recognises that there is a need to address the matter of cost efficiency and improved productivity in the Iron Ore Industry if we are to survive in a highly competitive Global market.
B. The M.U.A. is prepared to discuss with the Iron Ore producers ways of improving efficiency and lowering the unit costs of production.

C. We note that in the past Company spokesmen have talked about productivity issues but have failed to produce methods of measuring productivity. We suggest that Dr. N. F. Dufty in his 1984 Pilbara Iron Ore Industry paper propounded a criteria for measuring productivity. An examination of the Dufty proposition may be fruitful for all parties.

D. The M.U.A. realises that improved efficiency and productivity should lead to increased corporate profitability and we believe such profits should be re-invested in the Pilbara region. New technology and steel production methods make Secondary Processing in the Pilbara feasible.

E. It should be accepted by all parties that there will have to be frank and open discussions at all levels to secure the long term future of the industry. Concepts of absolute managerial prerogative must be set aside if we are to approach the problems in the dispassionate and objective manner.

F. The M.U.A. believes that the issue of lowering unit costs and improving efficiency must be debated at shop floor level. Consultation between union officials and their membership with full cooperation of management will be all important in this project.

G. Consequently, the M.U.A. proposes that we are ready to enter into meaningful discussions at industry and company level to assist in bringing about collective measures to remedy current deficiencies in the area of increased productivity and improved efficiency.
We therefore urge the companies to accept our propositions and join us as soon as possible in tackling these mutual problems.

That is quite a departure from what is being propounded by the New Right and the Opposition parties in their policies. The document was presented at the meeting and was welcomed by the representatives of the companies present. Incidentally, Robe River Iron Associates chose not to attend the meeting and also not to allow rank and file members of the unions to attend the meeting. So they were not included in the welcoming of this statement. But it gives an indication of the restraint the trade union movement in Australia is imposing upon itself in the long term interests of this nation. Hopefully, it is a restraint that will be spread more widely within the community.

Finally, the measures in the Appropriation Bills have been put forward by a responsible and responsive government. In doing so, we seek the co-operation of all sectors of Australian society in achieving a sound economic future for Australia. I commend the Bill to all honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time is short in this debate and I will not rehash the economic argument or go through the great list of failings of this Government and its inability to manage the economy any better than it can manage the Parliament. My colleagues have done that more eloquently and persuasively. Because time is short, I want to deal with only one aspect, which is an expenditure item within the Department of Defence of $10.099m for the project definition study for the new submarine. I do it at the second reading stage because it is more appropriate that I canvass some general issues now rather than at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of some astonishment to me that, when we have very large expenditures for some of our defence projects, the matters are never discussed in the Parliament, yet we spend days and days arguing over really trivial and ephemeral issues with expenditure of a few hundred thousand dollars. There has been no formal debate on this big issue of the new submarine program. There have been a number of contributions in this place and in the other place, but very few members of the Parliament have taken any interest in it. When we go back to the last big expenditure, the purchase of the F18, the new tactical fighter, I think I was the only person in either chamber who spoke about it. I notice that I drove the Australian Labor Party to distraction when I brought it up. But I make no apology for that. Very big sums of money are involved and these purchases have a consequence and an influence on the defence capability of this country that runs for 30 or 40 years.

While under the Westminster system the selection of the equipment and the conduct of the Department of Defence is a matter for the executive government of the day, it is quite proper that the members of the Parliament have their say and debate these issues. That is why today I will spend a few moments talking about the new submarine program because it will be the biggest defence program this country has ever written. In March 1985 the project cost was $2.6 billion. With the inflation rate that has been running since then, we can project that forward to a cost of about $3.6 billion today. I do not know what the tenders came in at when the tenders closed on 11 November, but it may well be more than $3.6 billion at today's prices. If we project ahead over the life of that program-I think the build time will be at least 15, maybe 20 years, for those boats, we are looking at a huge expenditure.

Now that we have an impoverished country, thanks to the Labor Party, we have a responsibility to make sure that we get value for our money because we are picking up a huge additional debt with this submarine program. But, more than the mere monetary side of it is the value of this equipment to the Australian defence forces. We have to be sure that we get the best for the money we spend because a lot will ride on this decision. Much of the deterrent capability that is the basis of Australia's defence will turn on the suitability of these submarines for the next 30 to 40 years. I cannot overemphasise the importance of making sure that we get what we are doing right. I regret to have to say that, on the evidence before us at the moment, we are not very reassured on that point.

In fact, it is fair comment to say that the need for the new submarines has not been established beyond reasonable doubt. It is clear that the Oberons we have are costly to maintain. They are now old boats. The big problem with them is the internal mechanical equipment. It is not beyond the wit of man to replace those pumps and the internal machinery and update them. Basically, there are no problems with the hulls. They have turned out to be an extraordinarily successful design and are not plagued by the fatigue problems that other submarines have. They go through a major refit every four or five years. The assessment of the boats that has been made at refit is that they are in first class condition and from a hull point of view are quite capable of staying in service for another 15 or 20 years. They must have their refits; if they do not have them at the nominated time, limitations will be imposed on their diving depth. Once they go through that refit, they go back to their original designed diving depth because the fittings that are subject to a fatigue life are replaced at refit.

They are very good boats. They are still the best diesel electric submarines around. They are very long range and they have the best weapons and sensors fitted to them of any diesel electric boat. We hope that the new boats we are buying will be better in that regard, but they will be better only in a matter of degree; it will not be a quantum jump forward. It is that that has to be considered against the price that we are paying for them. If we look at previous Navy equipment and the time, nearly 20 years ago, when we ordered the DDGs, they were a quantum jump ahead of the cruiser then in the fleet, HMAS Hobart. When we bought the F111s they were a quantum jump ahead of the Canberras and the Lincolns. Similarly, the F18 was a great jump ahead of the Mirages. In all those cases there was a very large change in the capability of the new equipment.

The new boats will be better only in degree. We hope that they will be quieter but no one knows that because none of the boats have been built. We know that they will not have as great a range, but the Oberons have an exceptional range. We hope that their weapons systems will be better, but again we do not know because they have not been developed. We hope that if engines like the fuel cells and the Stirling engine can be developed, they will have a considerably greater underwater endurance, but that has yet to be proven. It is rumoured that the Stirling engine, on which the Navy is banking a great deal, met some disastrous failure in the last two weeks on tests in Sweden. I am not surprised about that because the principle on which the Stirling engine is based is a very old principle. It goes back an awfully long way and no one has yet designed a practical one that really works. That is not to say that that will not be done or done in the near future, but the point is at the moment it has not been done.

The new submarine program falls into two parts-the design of the platform, which is the hull and the engines, and the weapons systems-the electronics, the detectors and the armament itself. Roughly the costs are split fifty-fifty-maybe it is 40 per cent-60 per cent, but it is of that order. The Navy invited tenders for the two separate components-the platform and the weapons systems. Regrettably, at the time the Navy showed no recognition at all publicly of the difficulties of integrating a weapons system with a platform. I will have more to say about that later.

I have read the tender document that was put out-it was a public document-for the hull design. It was a very comprehensive document. It contained some very specific things, and I would like to quote from two sections of it. Clause 1.1.6.1 called for `a design which meets the Royal Australian Navy required ship characteristics' and clause 1.1.6.2 calls for a design `which is a derivative of proven in-service design-I emphasise those words ``a proven in-service design''-of demonstrable performance and reliability where changes to incorporate particular RAN requirements constitute a low technical risk and do not involve significant design efforts. The application of up to date technology will be an important consideration'. The meaning of clause 1.1.6.2 is black and white-it is calling for a boat which has been built and which is in service.

There are some very obvious reasons why that should be done. In this country we would not dream of going to Lockheed, General Dynamics or McDonnell Douglas, even though they are very reputable and very competent aircraft builders, and saying: `We want an aircraft to do a specific task in Australia'. We would always say: `We want to see how suitable one of your designs that is already in service is for Australian needs'. We do that for very good reason. The major capital equipment that we buy will be in service for about 30 years. No piece of equipment can be bought off the shelf, out of the factory, and go through a 30-year service life without at least one major mid-life update in which its capabilities are changed significantly. Most importantly, the equipment has to be supported through its life in service. With an orphan design of three, four or six boats, which is the position in which the Navy has now put us, the question of through-life support is very, very dubious. It cannot be guaranteed in any sense at all. The only guarantee that one may be able to make about it is that it will be very difficult and horrendously expensive.

I come back to this comparison with the Army. We would not buy from anyone a tank that was not in service. We would not buy a design to meet special Australian characteristics. Yet this is precisely the position in which we are now in relation to the submarine project, despite clause 1.1.6.2 in the tender which called for a proven design. The absurdity of the situation is that those tenderers who responded to the request for tender and who had built or were building submarines which satisfied clause 1.1.6.2. were excluded. RDM of Holland and Vickers Shipbuilding and Engineering Ltd of the United Kingdom were excluded. Not only were they building boats but also they are very reputable, experienced companies. The contract was given to two of the minor league-the Mickey Mouse builders of the submarine world, the builders whom no reputable submarine power takes seriously. It is history now that the HDW-IKL complex-always the favoured son of the Navy-was awarded one of the places. Kockums was put in to make HDW look good. At the time tenders were lodged and accepted by the Navy neither hull satisfied the Royal Australian Navy required ship characteristics. The integrity of the hulls did not meet the Australian Navy design standards; nor were they boats that were in service.

HDW is blessed with a very effective sales team which makes a big thing about the large number of boats that it has built since the late 1940s. They have been built for the really great submarine powers of the world, such as Ecuador, Chile, Peru, Venezuela, Columbia, Greece and Turkey-countries that use submarines as status symbols on the presidential or the national day. It has also supplied boats to Norway, Denmark, the Federal Republic of Germany, Indonesia and India. All these are low technology boats. They are short ranged and shallow diving. The only examination that has been made of the HDW designs is the well publicised investigation that is a matter of public record on the United States congressional record. In the early 1980s when the US Navy was looking for diesel electric boats it found that HDW designs were specifically deficient on the grounds of silence, safety, maintainability and manning. One of the sad things about it was that the better known and more capable German designer Thyssens was excluded from the selection program, solely on the grounds that the RAN favoured HDW and it did not want two German designs on the short list.

I do not want to enumerate the many technical failings or difficulties with the design that we have accepted. I come back to the point that neither boat has been built and there is a very high technical risk in the path which we are following. One of the key things about a submarine is its noise signature. How noisy it is under water under all operating conditions cannot be established. Not even model studies that are meaningful have been done on these designs.

Another serious criticism relates to security. The design office for the German tenderer is within metres of the border with East Germany. The future of Germany is a matter for conjecture. Reunification between East and West Germany may take place. If that took place-it could within the lives of our boats-almost certainly Germany would have to adopt a position of neutrality, and through-life support for those boats would not be available. In Sweden there is evidence that the design parameters that were laid down, the technical details of the boats, have passed to the Soviets. That is a very important criticism. If the Soviets know the design characteristics of the Australian boats, we will lose some very important secrets. If one knows anything about submariners one will know that the one thing they will never talk about is the diving depth of the boat, for obvious reasons. If the ultimate depth to which the hull is designed to go is known, weapons used against the submarine can be programmed for that depth. The cavitation speeds of the propellor at various depths are also highly important. The fact that the Russians seem to have this evidence really compromises the whole program.

Many aspects about the selection process are disturbing. I have mentioned the elimination of the known builders. The pricings of the original tenderers are also a matter of some concern. Having built the boats, RDM from Holland and Vickers Shipbuilding and Engineering Ltd from the United Kingdom had a pretty fair idea of what they would cost. Their tenders were higher than the tender prices advanced by HDW and Kockums which had not built their designs. It now turns out that we are looking at a figure of about #100m sterling for the first of the Upholder class built by VSEL and, as the line proceeds, it is probable that the price will come down to about #75m or #80m sterling, which will make it considerably cheaper than the price of the HDW design. No matter how the dollar moves as a result of this Government's actions, that relationship will be maintained.

One of the other unusual things about the selection program is that now all the key personnel who were in the Navy and the Department of Defence at the time of the decision are no longer there. A continuity of assessment has been lost. Rear Admiral Rourke, Chief of Naval Materiel at the time, retired, and it was no secret that he was an HDW fan. Captain White was the head of the project. He had a great career ahead of him. He had an unblemished record in the Navy and would have gone on to be an admiral status without any difficulty at all. But Captain White, inexplicably, retired suddenly, and he went to work for Senator Button in his Department. Mr Harper, who was the submarine project design manager, who is a world figure in submarine design and certainly the most capable Australian in the technicalities of hull design and is regarded as the ultimate design authority in the world on the Oberon hulls-the British even refer to him from time to time when they have modification programs with their Oberon class-also retired prematurely. He went to work for HDW. I believe that that appointment was terminated very suddenly as a result of pressure from Australian sources. The break in continuity in the Department of Defence that we now have is very serious. I make it clear that that is only one of many factors about the selection process which are unsettling.

I am convinced that, in relation to the selection of the submarine, the Department of Defence acted dishonourably. I am not prepared to go as far as my colleague in another place and say that the Department acted dishonestly. I think that is an open question at present. I am certain that the tenderers did not all get equal consideration. I am aware that there are some very aggrieved companies, in RDM, Thyssen and VSEL. I am not concerned about their feelings, because there always are losers, but I am concerned that the process of selection was not fairly conducted. Further, I am not convinced that we have the best design that is possible. We have ended up with something that is very expensive and has a very high technical risk. So much for the hull.

The weapons system is much the same story, except that one of the two on the short list there has much better credentials in the field of submarine weapons systems than either of the hull builders have in their field. But even there, even though we have a very capable electronics company doing the design of the weapons system, the problem of integration remains. One can take equipment that works very well on the laboratory bench or in a different setting, in a different aircraft or a different ship. When that equipment is put into the chosen aircraft or ship, there can be enormous problems. There can be years of work and tens of millions or hundreds of millions of dollars in research and development programs to make it work in that setting. One of the two electronics companies that we have short-listed on the weapons system program is at present experiencing enormous difficulties-difficulties which seem to be insoluble for it-in fitting a weapons system to the boats of another nation. This illustrates the very great difficulty of integration of electronics into a platform.

I started out saying that I wished to speak about the $10m that we are spending this year for the project definition study. That study was funded originally for $25m. It is now apparently up to $35m. The purpose of the PDS is to make sure that the design works. That is a nonsense. One of the conditions was that it should be a proven design so that we did not have to spend money on it. We shall be spending $35m of Australian taxpayers' money to try to establish that these paper designs will work. We did not spend one cent when we bought the F18 because we bought a proven design, and that was why the contract was written that way. We shall be spending $35m of taxpayers' money quite unnecessarily. That should have been borne entirely by the tenderers, not by the taxpayers.

What is even worse is that the design has been rushed, and much of the essential data that should have been provided is not there in the PDS because there has not been time to provide it. For example, we do not know how quiet these boats are-yet submarines are found principally by their noise signature. Data on the noise emanating from them is absolutely essential. The estimates that we have are estimates only of their structural integrity and their fatigue life.

We come to the business of costing. The Department of Defence very foolishly let a contract for the PDS which is an open-ended contract. It said to the tenderers `You will build those boats for a certain fixed price', but it never defined what had to be in those boats for the price. What will happen is that tenderers will meet that price. They will say: `There is your boat, for X hundred million dollars; but if you want it to fight, if you want the weapons systems, the range and the rest of it, that will cost you X hundred million dollars more'. That is quite a wrong way to go. Those tenderers who tendered originally with an accurate costing have been excluded because of this.

Apart from the design, and moving away from the project design study, I should like to deal with the business of where the submarines are to be built, because this is one of the most unsavoury elements of the whole submarine program-the squalid squabbling in public as to where those boats will be built. Both the Navy and the Department of Defence have been very clever politically in this matter. They have been too clever by half. They have played on the greed of the various State governments, their cupidity, in holding out a carrot in the form of a $2.6 billion or $3.6 billion building program, the employment, the technology leap and all the rest of it, which will take place in their States if they get the contract. By so doing, they have turned the argument away from an examination as to the suitability of the design that has been accepted and even whether we need the boats at all.

There are two aspects to this. The first is where the boats are to be built, and the second is the pressure that is now coming on people in this Parliament and in the Department of Defence to press ahead at breakneck speed because of the jobs and the money that is involved in the program. Building submarines is a highly skilled task. Only one company in Australia, Vickers at Cockatoo, has a proven record in submarine maintenance and modification. Yet the Royal Australian Navy and the Department of Defence, at the time when the selection of the boats was made, had no serious formal discussions with that company at all. They talked to other companies in Australia, though, about constructing the new design. Not only did that fly in the face of common sense, because these are people with a proven capability in a very specialised field; Vickers also happens to be the only Australian company in the business. It is owned by Australian National Industries and the shareholders are Australian.

We have a government that brays about how it is now buying Australian made products for the Department of Defence, but in fact it does nothing for Australian industry. As we see with the PC9 design for the Air Force or the Steyr rifle for the Army, the Government has bought overseas on two orders which could well have gone to Australia. Consider the sophistry of the contenders for the program. They call themselves Australian companies-the Australian Submarine Corporation, which is Kockums; and Australian Marine Systems, which is HDW. The name `Australian' in these front companies is a misnomer.

This business of building the submarines has turned into a blatant pork-barrelling exercise. What I suspect will happen is that one State will be named as the prime assembly area and some fabrication will be done in other States; it will be spread around to keep everyone quiet. There will be big cost penalties in that, and there will also be very big safety problems, because one cannot guarantee quality control and quality assurance may not be guaranteed in that circumstance. Submarines are not like surface ships. They are very much like aeroplanes. They are inherently dangerous. I have very grave fears about the safety of submarines that are put together from components built all over Australia, the selection of those sites having been based on political grounds. This is precisely the situation in which the United States Government found itself with the Challenger program, and we know how tragically that ended in January this year on its launch. We are inviting precisely the same result with the Minister holding out the production sites as a bait to his political colleagues around Australia.

In conclusion, I want to talk about the Minister's haste to get a decision and contract signed. Let us get it right before we sign the contract. There will be a new government in this country within three months or 12 months. The incoming government will put the submarine program on hold, irrespective of what the contractual position is at the time. It will not matter what documents have been signed; it will not matter how many tonnes of metal have been cut. We will go back and evaluate the design and examine its suitability for Australian needs. We will work out whether it is adequate; we will work out whether we are getting value for money. No one has anything to fear if the design is the best and if it is the best value for money. We will not be blackmailed by the industrial complex telling us that jobs will be lost. That is nonsense. The order will still go ahead, but it might just be delayed a year or so.

The Opposition has been scarred by the Whitlam years. We came into government in 1975 and carried on with two disastrous contracts-the FFG design and the Leopard tank. The Leopard tank had a most unusual design, with a very light hull and a big gun. The Leopard II which replaced it is very different. But we honoured that contract. We honoured the FFG contract. In so doing we bought the most useless ship that the Royal Australian Navy has ever had. We will not be faced with the same situation with this submarine program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak in this debate on the Appropriation Bills today, although it gives me little joy to speak about the Australian economy. Following on from my learned colleague Senator MacGibbon, I wonder whether really this Government is trying to submerge us by taking us under the water in a submarine with the economy, or whether actually it is just trying to scuttle the whole of the Australian economy.
—Are you going to dazzle us with your wit for half an hour, Senator, or is that the only joke?

—No, I am not, Senator Zipper. The other day somebody said: `What do you have if you don't have a zipper?' I said: `You have a Senator Button'. The latest figures for our balance of payments give us a very clear picture of the appalling state into which this Government has put the economy. No longer can our once famous, now infamous, Treasurer (Mr Keating), the clock collector, blame the previous governments, the weather, external forces, or anything else that comes to his mind, for the economy. I wonder whether the clock collector has got his timing right or whether he actually has a watch that, most probably, is not waterproof and he has taken it under water.

SPEECH.PARA: The economy today truly stands as all the Australian Labor Party's own work. The downturn in industry-especially the motor vehicle industry- is a result of government policy. The cost of living is a result of Government actions and policy. Our massive and ever growing external debt is a result of Government actions and Government policy. High interest rates are a result of Government actions and Government policy. Australia today is in a mess, and words are not the solution. The Labor Party cannot keep trying to talk up the economy, and Australia is getting heartily sick of hearing that the economy is about to turn the corner, that things are about to start to improve, that interest rates are about to fall and that inflation is about to come down. They have heard all that over the last three years. Although they hear it, what they see is quite the reverse. Our annual inflation rate-currently something like 8.9 per cent-is still four or more times that of any of our major trading partners. Interest rates are still unacceptably high and will continue to stay up while our economy is in such a mess.

That comes as hard news for those in the rural sector, many of whom have battled soaring interest rates for over two years, along with drought and slumping world markets for their commodities. Also, just in the last day or two, they suffered the damaged wheat situation that comes from heavy rains falling on ripe wheat. Interest rates have been kept high by this Government, in an attempt to attract overseas capital. Many farmers have hung on in the last few years in the belief that the Government would do as it promised-that it would return Australia to the strong economic growth that we have had in the past. They hoped relief would come in the rural statement in April of the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr John Kerin. In that statement he claimed:

No government has ever presented such a comprehensive, wide-ranging policy review from the standpoint of the rural, or any other, sector. No government has ever been so active in promoting the revenue concerns of Australian agriculture; and no government has ever given more recognition to the needs of all residents of rural and provincial Australia.

Frankly, I have cattle at home that produce better fertiliser than that. What a lot of hot air, wasted words and meaningless phrases. What hope did that give to the rural sector? But that was in April. What has happened since? For starters, the consumer price index has recorded its largest increase since the December 1982 quarter. Interestingly enough, there has been quite a dramatic difference between the CPI increase of the city in which I have my electorate office, the city of Tamworth, and those of the major capital cities of Australia. For example, in the survey that I did in that city it was found that house fuel rose by 14.23 per cent, whereas the capital cities average was 1.7 per cent. For light, the capital cities average CPI rise was 1.7 per cent; in the Tamworth area it was 5 per cent. For fuel, in the major capital cities the CPI rise was 6.8 per cent, whereas in Tamworth it was 11.86 per cent-a 12 per cent increase for diesel fuel and a 14.23 per cent increase for heating oil. For wine and spirits, the capital cities average rise was 6.4 per cent; in Tamworth the rise was 20 per cent.

Unemployment has also risen, with the latest September figures reaching some 8.4 per cent. The current account deficit has soared, with the latest figure being $1.735 billion-a record. That sounded warning bells throughout the economy. That is something like $50m per day or $2m per hour. Of course, the Budget holds no great hopes either. The Budget suggests a lower deficit target of some $3.5 billion, but this will be achieved only through increased taxes. In its first three years the Labor Government has attempted to produce an expenditure led recovery. In doing so it has run up a total deficit of some $20.3 billion. As we all know, the hallmarks of Labor governments are big government, big spending, increased taxation and big interference in our lives. This Budget and this Government are living up to reputation on all three counts. On the question of restraint, this Government works on the premise that one should hit the productive and assist the unproductive.

Let me cite some of the better examples of just how carefully this Government is managing our taxes. It has provided $440 a week for four people over 18 weeks to train as clowns. That is really not as funny as it sounds. It has given $11,000 to a women's group to design a surfboard for women. This Government has provided $52,000 to the Victorian Builders Labourers Federation for artists and muralists. With spending like this is it any wonder that the economy is in such a mess? The Treasurer himself, in his Budget Speech, said Australia was facing a financial crisis and becoming a banana republic. Let me just quote from an article by Angela Mackay and Terence Maher on the front page of today's Australian Financial Review:
According to Mr White, union moves for productivity-based wage claims and superannuation payments were out of the question in a climate of mounting foreign debt and trade deficits.
And he accused the Federal Government of failing to create a climate for investment to take advantage of increased competitiveness resulting from recent sharp falls in the Australian dollar.
Mr White, former head of the Australian Business council, asked: `Why is the Government imposing such savage imposts on business?'

Wearing a badge depicting the Australian flag on his tie, Mr White asked rhetorically whether Australia had to wait until it was `a Brazil' before action was taken to correct our lack of competitiveness.

I ask the Government why it is not doing something about stopping this country slipping the way it is slipping at this stage. Australia is not just in a financial mess; it is also in a legislative mess. It would seem that this Government cannot even get its legislation drafted properly. The fringe benefits tax fiasco must rate as an all-time classic example of bad legislation badly managed and woefully inappropriate. In fact in the Committee stage of the debate on that legislation numerous people tried to point out some of the anomalies likely to happen, and they have now happened. I think it is time the Government actually scrapped it completely and got on with the job of putting incentive back into the community.

Budgets have been drafted on anticipated revenues from the FBT, but to get that extra revenue the Government has had to spend millions and now, the Government claims, unintended consequences have thrown these financial calculations out the door. Of course, unintended consequences, such as a 30 per cent drop in car sales, were predicted and the Government was told that it would happen. I chose to ignore it, just as it chose to ignore other unintended consequences which were pointed out to it at that time. In many cases in this chamber, and before the legislation was passed, as I have already said, this Government ignored any of the comments and suggestions made as regards that iniquitous tax.

Of course, the fringe benefits tax legislation is not the only legislation with which there have been major problems. There have been similar bunglings with capital gains tax changes and for months the Treasurer kept assuring Australia in general and the Opposition in particular that there was nothing wrong with the legislation. The fact that we now have Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is clear evidence that in fact the legislation was far from perfect. The Australia Card Bill is another example of bad legislation, shabbily drafted, but in this case it will not have the opportunity to get to the amendment stage. I quote what Mr Frank Costigan, QC, said when he appeared before the Senate Select Committee on an Australia Card, as reported at pages 1203-4:

There is no doubt that the introduction of an Australia Card of the kind contemplated by the submissions that I have read is a significant intrusion into individual privacy. I have no doubt at all about that . . . I have formed a judgment about it, and I am very strongly opposed to the introduction of an Australia Card. I think the benefits that might flow from it are to some extent illusory, certainly speculative, and can be achieved by other means.

Bill after Bill and policy after policy are changed from one month to another as flaws are found. Is that the way to run a country? It is not just the legislative program that is a mess. The Treasurer's Round-up for October is sorry reading. I would like to contemplate that it may be the last round-up. For example, private new capital expenditure has declined, housing finance approvals have fallen, and building approvals for new dwellings have fallen also. And the economy continues its downward slide. It is no good this Government pushing the State of the economy under the carpet or trying to take us into the depths of the water, as I said at the beginning of this speech. It is still not facing up to its overspending. It is still not facing up to the holding of wage demands and it is not facing up to advising the Australian community that all of us are living beyond our means. In reality this Government, the Hawke Labor Government, is turning Australia into a faceless country. It is time the people of Australia were told the truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate on the Appropriation Bills to say just a few words on some issues which have arisen in recent days and on which I believe a comment needs to be made from this side of the Parliament. I will not take the Senate's time unduly because many of the matters I wish to raise will be raised during the Committee stage of the debate. I want to comment particularly on an attack on Wednesday of this week on a wide range of people-seven or eight, I think-by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in reply to a dorothy dix question from his own side of the chamber. He made a swingeing and deplorable attack on many people, including in particular one of Australia's leading businessmen, Mr John Elliott. I appreciate that Senator Walsh will probably, in response, portray me as defending Mr Elliott because he occupies a leading position in my party organisation. I am commenting on the issue not for that reason at all but because Mr Elliott is one of Australia's leading businessmen. He is one of those people in the community, fortunately an increasing number, who are really getting Australia's act together in terms of where we are going in the world. They are doing it despite the best intentions and endeavours of this Government to frustrate business activity, incentive and endeavour wherever they raise their heads. I deplore the use of this Parliament to make personal attacks on people in the way in which particularly Senator Walsh but other members of the Government do. It is a very cowardly form of approach to attack under privilege people who have no way of responding in a like manner. I take very much the point that his President alluded to the other day in response to a comment by Senator Chaney: I hope that these matters will be raised in the Privileges Committee of this Senate before too long.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming back to the detail, the Minister, Senator Walsh, attacked Mr Elliott for building an industrial and manufacturing base in Australia, having started with very limited personal resources. Surely that is the precise activity we ought to be encouraging in this country. How on earth can we build a nation, a manufacturing sector or a financial sector if we are not to have people who are prepared to put themselves at risk, to work hard, to strive and to achieve-not just on their own behalf but, for the nation as a whole? It ill suits a Government Minister such as Senator Walsh to make outrageous and scurrilous statements about any figure in the Australian community when he knows perfectly well that if he said them outside this place he would have criminal proceedings taken against him immediately.

Why then did Senator Walsh attack Mr Elliott? He appears to have attacked Mr Elliott because Mr Elliott spelled out in simple arithmetic a little earlier the fact that investment in Australia is a very difficult proposition nowadays compared with investment in other countries because of our high tax rates and high interest rates. By the way, the Australian company tax rate, now at 49 per cent, I understand is the highest in the world, certainly the Western world. We have, with our interest rate structure today, the highest real interest rates in the Western world. Those two factors, the greatest possible inhibitors of investment in this country, are due primarily to the policies of this Government. That is why Senator Walsh was so reactive because he knows as well as I do that his Government's policies have led to this situation. I wish to put on the public record my disgust at the attacks on people such as Mr Elliott. This attack is just one example of the attacks that are taking place in this Parliament. Helpful comments that are made in the community are completely distorted and demeaned in this place.

Senator Walsh said that Mr Elliott had been engaged in `de facto embezzlement' as a result of the activities associated with the Henry Jones takeover some years ago. He accused Mr Elliott of making a tax free profit in a way which, by implication and innuendo, was somehow illegal. I point out to the Senate that all the profit that was made on those transactions and the development of the Henry Jones industrial vehicle was entirely within the taxation law of this country at the time. These were entirely legal transactions. Had the Government objected to them at the time presumably it would have made the necessary changes to the law. Regardless of whether changes are made after the event, it is absolutely disgusting that an action by any person in the community which was legal at the time can be subsequently regaled as being in some way illegal or underhand. I really detest that sort of approach. Mr Elliott responded to this attack yesterday in the media and it is worth recalling some of the things that he said. His comments should certainly be set out in the public record of the Senate. He said that new investment in Australia is being inhibited by high interest rates and the highest tax rates in the world. He also said, quite rightly:
That's what makes it one of the least attractive places to invest.

He pointed out that in terms of the cost structures in Australia at present, this country is now highly competitive with the rest of the Western world. Mr Elliott even said-and I am not sure that he is right-that the cost structures in Australia were now the lowest in the Western world. However, he pointed out also that there is not enough margin in Australia on which to predicate investments. This is because of our tax and interest rates structure. Mr Elliott said that in order to earn an 18 per cent after-tax return on investment debt and equity funds, Australian companies need, on a pre-tax and pre-interest rate basis, a return of at least 25 per cent. That compares with less than 15 per cent-in fact, 14.8 per cent-in Hong Kong; 16.7 per cent in the United States; and 17.8 per cent in Britain. Then one must compare the interest rates of different countries. Borrowings in the United States, according to Mr Elliott, can be obtained at interest rates of between 7 and 8 per cent. In Australia the borrowing rates are 17 to 18 per cent. As he quite rightly said, it is a matter of simple arithmetic as to why people are having grave doubts about investing in the productive sector of this economy. It is about time that this Government woke up to that fact: There is no point in imploring business to invest in Australia if we do not set the framework to enable it to make a profit on its investment. That is the situation that exists in this country today because of our interest rate and tax rate structures.

Incidentally, I point out to honourable senators that one of the other great critics of Mr Elliott's statement a few weeks ago when he talked about the difficulties of getting a return on investment in Australia, was the Victorian Labor Premier, Mr Cain, who accused people who invest overseas of `ratting' on Australia. It is very interesting to note a report that was tabled in the Victorian Parliament two days ago. The first report of the Victorian Government's new notorious and desperately expensive Work Care scheme-a scheme that attracts a lot of income from employers-showed that of the income from that scheme in its first year of operation $70m, or 18.5 per cent of its total income, was invested overseas. Why was it invested overseas? Why would the Cain Government invest 18.5 per cent of the total income of this Government instrumentality overseas? It was done in order to earn a return on investment in exactly the same way that business people in this country seek to earn a return. It is about time that Labor governments, both Federal and State, got their acts together and grasped at least a basic simple comprehension of what is required to make the private sector of this country operate and perform.

The efforts of this Government in inhibiting productive investment are no more than an indication that it has learnt nothing in its four years in office about the real operations of the private sector, which is the powerhouse income and wealth generator of this country. As a result of that it is no wonder that our economy has ground to a halt. For three successive quarters we have had negative growth in Australia. That information was released surreptitiously by the Treasurer's principal adviser. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) himself did not have the gumption to tell us. The information was leaked surreptitiously on the other side of the world that there will be no domestic growth in this country this year. If there is to be any growth at all in the economy it will come entirely from the external sector.

When one looks at the external sector one really wonders how on earth that growth could possibly eventuate. In Australia today we have a balance of payments deficit on current account that absolutely boggles the mind. Last month alone we were in debt, in hock, to the rest of the world to the tune of $1,735 billion-not far short of $2,000m. There were some factors in that that must be taken into account in assessing an annual rate, but the fact is that we are running a deficit with the rest of the world of something like $17,000m this year on top of a deficit of about $14,000m last year. To finance that debt we are now borrowing at a rate which puts us amongst the highest borrowers in the world, including the Third World countries whom we used to denigrate so much because of their external indebtedness. We have put ourselves in a position where our external debt is one of the most horrendous in the world. We have a government that treats with lax disdain the problems of out external account, especially when it comes to actually doing something about it. Senator Button talks in the Senate about the long and medium term problems facing Australia in relation to getting the external situation right but 50 metres away, on the other side of this building, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) are trying to talk up the economy and talk down our external account problems in a way which is totally misleading.

We have not been told what this Government's exchange rate or interest rate policies are. We appear now to have a situation where we have the Government, or the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, saying that we have a floating exchange rate.
