But everyone in the financial markets knows that the Reserve Bank of Australia put a floor under the Australian dollar back in July when Australian Reserves absolutely haemorrhaged as a result of what was going on in the Australian economy at that time. There was Reserve Bank intervention on a massive scale. It lost us a fortune in international reserves to shore up the level of the dollar. Now, in the last month or so, it appears that the Reserve Bank is buying in the market to keep the value of the Australian dollar from rising too high.

I do not pass judgmental comment on those actions but I do say, though, that it is absolutely imperative for the Government to tell the Australian people, the Australian economy and Australian markets just what its exchange rate policy is. At the moment the Government appears to be acting almost to fix the exchange rate whilst having a floating interest rate structure. That is the most interesting development in economic policy that appears to have occurred in this country in a long time. Having a near-fixed exchange rate and a floating interest rate completely turns on its head the sort of policy that the Government until recently was saying we had. It is imperative for the Government to come clean and tell us what its exchange rate and interest rate policies are.

At the end of the day it is the fundamentals of our economic situation that will determine how our country develops. It is the fundamentals that will determine whether the industry policies that either this Government or the incoming coalition government pursue, will work. There is no point in trying to restructure the Australian economy in an industrial sense if we do not get things right in relation to exchange rates, interest rates and the macro-environment in which productive activity in this country has to take place. I fear very gravely for the future of this economy unless fundamental changes are made to some of our key macroeconomic policies, not least of which is budgetary policy, because we have a Government that is not seized of the problems facing the long term future of this country; we have a Government which is treating almost as a yawn the fact that we have not only a record external debt but also a record internal debt. Australia now owes the rest of the world $17,000 for every taxpayer in Australia. That is an enormous debt cast over each and every Australian. The Government seems not even to recognise that that is a problem. It goes on in successive years to record new highs in government spending and therefore in government taxes and borrowings.

The Appropriation Bills the subject of debate today are the Bills of a Budget which is totally out of tune with the needs of this country in terms of the economic parameters and the environment in which the productive sector and all Australians are attempting to operate and to increase the prosperity of Australia and the living standards of us all. Unless this Government takes urgent action to do something about putting its spending house in order-by that I mean if the Government does not have a mini-Budget very early in the new year, if not by the end of this year-the problems which the present Budget has brought on, on top of the three preceding Budgets, will be enormously compounded in 1987 and we will run the risk as a nation of going into severe recession. So I do call on the Government as a matter of the greatest urgency to review its Budget strategy. It was the wrong strategy when the Budget was introduced in August; it is even more wrong today. It is imperative that the strategy be changed, it is imperative that the Government introduce a mini-Budget as soon as possible and it is imperative that it tells the Australian people and brings the Australian people into its confidence about where it is going in terms of this nation's economic policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget brought down by Treasurer, Paul Keating, on the night of 19 August probably represents the most important Budget to come before the Parliament in 40 years. It was the first time in those 40 years that any Australian government really attempted to cut government spending. It certainly contained some of the horror features that caused so much comment and heartache in the lead-up to its presentation. No Budget which increases taxation, reverses previous policy and admits that living standards will have to decline in the short term could be expected to escape that sort of labelling. However, it is the most economically responsible and politically honest Budget this place has ever seen. It is in sharp contrast to the rubbery Budgets that Messrs Howard and Lynch presented during the years of the Fraser Government. It shows that this Government is deadly serious about getting the Australian economy back on the road to sound development.
—It is deadly.
—I do not know how deadly it is, but I sincerely hope that Senator Withers is not too deadly. Long live John Howard; long may he reign. We love him; we need him.

—It has a bit to do with Senator Withers. I am told he is the one who is going around to the honourable senator's office, knocking on his door and asking: `Will you agree to knock off your leader?' Why does the honourable senator not tell us now where he stands?

—Most things are. The conservative parties in this country have had a pretty good run at government. The Australian Labor Party has been in government for very few of the years since World War II. The framework of this Budget had to be undertaken considering the very real problems of the decline in our terms of trade. It is worth looking at why we have this problem. Why are we in this situation? The major problem we have at the moment is the current account deficit, which is running at approximately $14 billion per annum. That situation has not been brought about by excessive wage increases, it has not been brought about by militant trade unions and it has not been brought about by reckless government spending.
—Of course it has.

—Most rational-I use the word `rational', so Senator Lewis is excluded-economic observers acknowledge that the real problem has been the decline in the terms of trade. If we were able today to secure the prices for our exports that we were achieving at the end of 1984, as a nation we would be earning $6 billion a year more. —It is minimal in terms of the sorts of deficits Malcolm Fraser was able to produce. Look at what he did with the resources boom, which I will get to in a second. The former Government really knew how to muck up an economy. One of the reasons for the current account deficit, in a sense, was this Government's tremendous success with growth rates. There has been phenomenal growth in imports. Because of buoyancy and a surge in the economy our domestic demand picked up enormously, imports grew substantially, and our trading partners did not achieve a rate of growth equal to ours and were, therefore, not buying our exports at the same rate as we were growing. That is one of the fundamental reasons for the current account deficit. Hence the Government's strategy in this Budget was to gear back the rate of economic growth. The Opposition, when in government, was flat out trying to lift it. It could not. It did not have a clue.

SPEECH.PARA: A further reason why imports were continuing to grow at such a rate was that our export performance did not measure up. Why did it not measure up? Conservative parties in their 30 years of government since the Second World War, because of their inward looking, misguided, selfish, miserable policies-particularly because the then Country Party's tail was always wagging the Liberal dog-gradually rendered our manufacturing industries uncompetitive. They gradually tore at its heart and gradually stripped it of its competitive edge. The current account deficit that we have today is going to be fixed because this Government has policies in its Budget to lift the manufacturing sector to make sure it gets back to the performance level it ought to have been at and would have been at if the lot opposite had not had 30 years attempting to wreck it.

While on the question of debt I will try to put to rest some of the claims made by members of the Opposition and their more vocal supporters around Australia, particularly those in the New Right, their real masters. It is true that in June this year Australia's debt stood at some $65 billion. But one of the things never referred to by the Opposition is the fact that only 35 per cent of that debt is public debt. Of that total, less than $14 billion is Commonwealth debt. What members of the Opposition fail to understand and fail to ever mention is the fact that the debt is so high because of the aggregate borrowings of corporations in Australia, many of them led by very prominent businessmen who hold very high office in the Liberal Party-if that is an honour these days; some of them still consider it such but most of them are looking closely at whether they should support the Liberal Party at all. These people have borrowed great sums of money overseas. Why have they done that? Far from what John Elliott `I would not invest here' has done, they have done exactly that-they have invested it here, because we have created an economy in which those businesses can grow. So they are prepared to spend money on doing just that.

Let us look at some elements of the Budget in more detail and look at how it comes to grips with the fundamental problems facing our economy. It does not hold out the traditional carrots in the form of financial protectionist bribes, the likes of which we saw so often during the 30 years of varying degrees of sleaziness; rather it is aimed at restoring a climate of confidence for producers and exporters. Our domestic economy and our standard of living must adjust to those changed circumstances. The adjustments required involve greater self-sufficiency as a nation.

—While I have been in this chamber, Senator Watson and I have had one thing that separates us-no, we have many actually, apart from this enormous gulf-and it is this: I have always been honest in this chamber. INTERJECT.PARA: Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first department mentioned in Group A is the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. Bearing in mind the shortness of time I intend to address my remarks only very briefly to the estimates for that Department. Quite clearly, this is a major area of concern for the Government and the Opposition, given the very difficult economic circumstances into which this country has been led by the current Government. We have seen a very substantial change in the last 18 months or so in the value of the Australian dollar which has caused enormous difficulties for Australian industries as they adjust to the change induced by the very substantial fall in the dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: In many industries that has meant a very big increase in the cost of inputs into particular industries. Let me instance several of the manufacturing industries in my State of South Australia. Of course, we know about the motor vehicle industry insofar as it has been greatly affected by the very substantial input of imported materials coming chiefly from Japan as a result of the rising value of the yen and the falling price of the Australian dollar relative thereto. This has meant that the cost of manufacture of vehicles in South Australia has risen and, consequently, tends to offset the advantages that may have come through other savings in the area of wage costs and so on. The imposition of the fringe benefits tax and also the new provisions relating to lead-free petrol and other matters such as that have increased the tendency towards higher costs through the effect of the devaluation of inputs into industry. That has meant higher costs to the consumer and a falling market for motor vehicles which is very substantial. Senator Elstob, from South Australia, would know very well that vehicle production this year has fallen by some 170,000 units. It is anticipated that that trend will continue for the next two to three years and will have a dramatic impact on the industry in South Australia.

Not only has the motor vehicle industry been affected but also we know of the effect on smaller industries, such as the wine industry in South Australia. We have seen the impact of increased costs of chemicals, of corks, of the kinds of materials that are used in the winemaking processes, which have risen dramatically by percentages upwards of 60 per cent and added substantially to the cost of wine production in South Australia. That has come at a time when there has been a substantial imposition of extra costs by this Government through the imposition of a sales tax on wine, which has affected the market for wine production rather seriously and, consequently, has led to a downturn in employment opportunities and gross employment in the wine industry.

Let me just quote figures to indicate employment numbers last year in the wine industry. The total number of people directly employed in the wine industry in Australia, just after the Government imposed its first sales tax increase of 10 per cent in 1984, was 6,000. That number is now reduced to 5,000-a net loss of 1,000 people out of a small but very important industry to South Australia. Consequently, that has had an effect which is flowing through the rest of Australia's economy. Taken with the downturn such as we are seeing through the substantial fall-off in the production of motor vehicles, it really does not lead one to a very positive and confident attitude for the outlook of manufacturing and industry generally in my home State. One would hope that the Government, through its industry and technology policies and the development of alternatives in the future, will have due regard to the problems of special industries such as those I have just outlined and will undertake positive policies to ensure that development is improved in those industries in the future.

We know that the Government is very keen to promote itself as something of a supporter of private enterprise. Yet, given the opportunities to do so, all it has done is impose more and more taxes on Australian manufacturers and Australian industry generally and destroy the opportunities for industry to look after itself. We have seen the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax introduced at a time when confidence needed to be built up. This has led to a destruction of enterprise in this country. Clearly, that is a wrong approach by any government, but this Government appears to be addicted to that kind of approach. It does not know when it puts out its right hand what its left hand is doing. Consequently, it gets its industry policies totally confused with its taxation and other policies and never quite gets its act together. This is having a very disruptive effect on the economic development of Australia and this must reduce the capacity of Australian industry to be able to handle its own affairs in the future.

I think it is time that this Government woke up to the fact that it is destroying the capacity of Australian industry to develop right at a time when the reverse ought to be occurring. What it should do at this time to demonstrate its faith in Australian industry and Australian enterprise is remove those crazy, lunatic investment-destroying imposts, such as the capital gains tax, the lump sum superannuation tax and, above all, the fringe benefits tax, which are so destructive of incentive and enterprise in this country. It is time the Government woke up to that fact. It is time it started to do something positive for Australian industry.

There has been an increase in the numbers but the increase varies from place to place. In recent times there has been an increase in admissions to Alice Springs Hospital from an annual average of five or six patients to, I think, 22 patients, 20 of whom are from South Australia. There was one death from petrol sniffing in the Alice Springs Hospital early this month. The Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy met earlier this month. Officials and Ministers representing all of the Commonwealth and State departments of health, Aboriginal affairs and community welfare discussed petrol sniffing in the Aboriginal communities, expressed their concern and established a small special task force, convened by the Northern Territory Government but comprising members from South Australia, Western Australia and the Commonwealth, to prepare an action plan for consideration by relevant Ministers meeting in Alice Springs in the next week or two. The plan will have to propose strategies for more effective co-ordination between the relevant authorities, ways of improving delivery of prevention and treatment services and means of improving quickly the knowledge about petrol sniffing. As in all areas of Aboriginal health, it is clear that any program will have to involve the Aboriginal communities, particularly the parents. It will have to take into account the very difficult social conditions that lead to this sort of behaviour. For instance, as with trachoma, the superficial problem is part of a total health problem and involves consideration of the total problems facing Aboriginal communities, particularly those young Aboriginals who, having received an education, find that that education is of very little use or relevance to them in their conditions. I hope that the task force will report soon. I will seek any further information from the Minister for Health and report to the Senate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer the Minister to his statement in the Senate on 29 May this year in relation to using the Australian War Memorial for a function associated with the proclamation of the controversial Veterans' Entitlements Act. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: The Department therefore took steps to itemise suitable venues for the holding of such a function. The Department then made the decision that the suitable place for the proclamation ceremony would be the Australian War Memorial.
I ask whether it is a fact that in the Jones report on the War Memorial administration a minute is detailed from the Minister's office, signed by a senior staffer, which states:
He-
the Minister-
would like a ceremony arranged at the War Memorial.
I ask the Minister: Why did he fail to tell the Senate that it was his request that the Australian War Memorial be used for the function?

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is, as I have indicated and as Senator Lewis mentioned in the earlier part of his question, that the Department chose the Australian War Memorial for the purpose of the proclamation ceremony. I was not aware then that the responsibility for assisting with the organisation of the function was passed to a member of my staff who in her own right communicated with the public relations section of the Department of Veterans' Affairs to organise the function. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask whether the Minister can explain how it was that Mr Jones found:

QUESTION.PARA: In the circumstances, the conclusion by the Director and his staff that the function was being held at the Memorial as a result of a ministerial direction does not seem unreasonable.
Can he explain why he bucketed Mr Flemming over this matter in the light of that finding?

TALK.START.PARA: —Never at any time did I direct the Australian War Memorial to perform the function or to make its premises available for the function. It was a decision of the Department to hold the function. It was a decision of the Department that it should be held at the Australian War Memorial. It was then the responsibility of the Department and of an officer from my office, as well as the persons involved in the War Memorial, to organise the function, who was to be invited and so on. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED CLOSURE OF QUEEN ELIZABETH II MEDICAL CENTRE AND MELVILLE REHABILITATION CENTRE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Community Services. What is the reasoning behind the Government's proposal to close the Queen Elizabeth II Medical Centre and Melville Rehabilitation Centre? What plans does the Department have to ensure that existing clients will not be disadvantaged by the planned closures? How can the Government continue to provide the same level of service to future clients as is provided at present? What facilities, similar to those available at QEII and Melville, will be available to clients after the closures? For what will the centres be used afterwards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision of the Commonwealth to close and sell major Commonwealth owned rehabilitation services in the next 12 months is part of the ongoing plan to reform the role of the Commonwealth rehabilitation service generally. The Commonwealth rehabilitation service was established in the post-war years in a vacuum. There was essentially no rehabilitation service within Australia. At that time and since then the large rehabilitation institutions were and have been built in most capital cities, including the ones mentioned by Senator Coleman. As a result of the siting of these centres and as a result of the development of the cities in which they were sited, there has been a major misallocation of resources in rehabilitation. For instance, in Western Australia up to 25 per cent of the costs of rehabilitation at the Melville Rehabilitation Centre was spent in transporting patients to and from the rehabilitation centre. When we had a residence at the Glen Waverley Rehabilitation Centre in Melbourne, it would have been cheaper to send the residents to Hawaii for a fortnight than to put them in that rehabilitation centre. The demographic centre of Sydney is around Parramatta in the western suburbs, yet one of our centres is in Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, QEII, which was referred to by Senator Coleman, and the other is on the far North Shore.

ANSWER.PARA: We are providing rehabilitation services through regional units where the clients are so that we can extend our services and increase the number of clients with whom we deal, so that we can act in co-operation with the State governments and the increasing number of private rehabilitation services to ensure an equitable distribution of services. We are now planning, in conjunction with the States, to achieve this. We have guaranteed, and I repeat the guarantee, that there will be no loss of services as a result of these actions. Where it is necessary, part of the sale of rehabilitation centres will be provided with a lease-back arrangement if we have to maintain services in existing areas while new ones or different ones are developed. I point out that the sorts of services described in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday-gymnasium facilities, swimming pools and training facilities-are available elsewhere and the Government will be able to arrange and pay for, if necessary, access to these services by rehabilitation clients.

It is of considerable disappointment to me that I noticed today that the Australian Medical Association has put out a rather inflammatory Press statement concerning the closure of some of the rehabilitation centres, saying that thousands of people who have been severely disabled by sickness or injury will have a shadow of doubt and uncertainty hanging over their futures. The first statement in the Press release says that I took over the Commonwealth rehabilitation service from the Department of Health. I did not. The Commonwealth rehabilitation service was in the Department of Social Security and came to the Department of Community Services in the split. It is that obsession of the AMA and others that rehabilitation is a medical process alone which has led to the difficulties that we now have. Medical rehabilitation is only part of general rehabilitation. The States and State hospitals are, and will continue to be, predominantly involved in medical rehabilitation. We will continue to provide, where necessary, the medical skills necessary for rehabilitation but, by and large, we will be involved in a counselling and brokerage role to improve, not lessen, the position of people in this country needing rehabilitation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, although I acknowledge that it may be more appropriately directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. I remind the Minister of a statement in the 1986-87 `Women's Budget Program' document that `significant reductions in the total level of overseas development assistance are likely to have a disproportionately adverse impact on women's participation in development activities'. In light of the Government's claim to be seeking to improve the position and status of women, can the Minister explain the rationale behind and the impact on women of the following: A 100 per cent cut in Australia's contribution to the United Nations Development Fund for Women; a 72 per cent cut in Australia's contribution to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities; a 20 per cent cut in Australia's contribution to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees; and a 90 per cent cut in Australia's contribution to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees in the Near East? Can the Minister also explain the effect that the 12.8 per cent drop in official development assistance will have on the ability of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau to supplement fully and evaluate its policy on women and development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information about the matters raised in Senator Haines's question. Despite cuts to Australia's overseas aid program in the last Budget, Australia continues to contribute to a range of international organisations that are important in assisting women. The Government does not consider that its commitment to issues of special significance to women in development can be expressed only in terms of funding commitments to these two particular organisations. Both the United Nations Development Fund and the United Nations Children's Fund, which receive significant Australian support, undertake projects focusing on the developmental needs of women. Lesser cuts to UNFPA and UNDFW would have been made at the expense of other key agencies.

ANSWER.PARA: Reductions in Australia's contribution to the UNFPA do not signal a reduced commitment to UNFPA's mandated responsibilities, nor do they signal a diminished focus within the overall aid program on important population issues relevant to development. In 1986-87 Australia is still contributing $350,000 to the Planned Parenthood Federation and $110,000 to the Population Council, as well as $870,000 for the World Health Organisation's special programs, including research, development and training in reproduction. Senator Haines's question touched upon some other issues. I will refer them to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for reply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to an article in the West Australian this morning headlined `More backing for ID card'? I ask the Minister whether the article contains the following statements by the Director of the Taxpayers Association, Mr Eric Risstrom, in relation to the Australia Card:

QUESTION.PARA: I am completely convinced that the majority of the Australian public wants it.
Furthermore, the majority of the Australian public needs it because I can see a tax cut of as much as 15 per cent at the end of the line.
I ask the Minister: Is the tax cut figure of 15 per cent an accurate estimate of the benefits to the Australian public of the Australia Card?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have indeed seen the article in the West Australian, part of which Senator Sibraa has quoted. I should add one or two lines to Senator Sibraa's quote, as Mr Risstrom said the system would lead to tax cuts of up to 15 per cent and would be a boon to honest taxpayers. That is, of course, a very accurate description of what the Australia Card would be-a boon to honest taxpayers. He said that he is completely convinced that the majority of the Australian public wants it and that he believes in it much more than he did a year ago.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of the reasoning behind Mr Risstrom's estimate of tax reductions of 15 per cent consequent upon the introduction of the Australia Card, but certainly there are very large benefits to honest taxpayers in its introduction. The amounts of money would grow over time, but the official estimates are that in the very first year it would yield an additional $700m in tax revenue-that is, $700m of tax would be paid by people who are presently evading tax-and that it would save around $300m a year in social security fraud. That adds up to a figure of $1 billion-the official estimate. Mr Risstrom's figure is somewhat higher than that. Who is to say that Mr Risstrom is wrong? Certainly, the official estimates, as such official estimates usually are, are rather conservative, and there is no doubt that the savings would grow over time, as compared with the continuation of a society without identity cards, as we have now. Mr Risstrom has placed himself in very good company on this issue. For example, Senator Haines said at the Tax Summit:

Furthermore, the use of identity cards to limit tax avoidance-for example, the holding down of two jobs by people using different names-and social security fraud, including maintenance avoidance, must be considered.

Mr Greiner, the Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales, said of the introduction of national identity cards: `They are in the interests of the community'. He said that only people who were acting dishonestly had anything to fear. Mr Greiner is completely right about that. On 15 September 1985 John Howard said, in reply to the question `. . . where do you stand on the proposed ID card?' from Laurie Oakes:
I personally see some merit in having an ID card providing the civil liberties concerns that people have voiced can be looked after-
I interpolate that they have been-

and provided the Government can satisfy the community that there is some cost benefit in it. I haven't gone overboard in supporting it, but, as a matter of principle, I think there is some merit in giving it . . . consideration.
When asked about his professed belief in deregulation and the introduction of the card, Mr Howard said:
I don't think there is any inconsistency. I mean, the United States has had a social security card for generations and yet the United States economy is the most deregulated economy in the world.

And so on, and so on. In other words, Mr Risstrom is in very good company and the only reason that some people in the Opposition have had a change of heart on this issue is that their tax evader friends have been putting political pressure on them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I hope that he can answer it a bit more confidently than he did the last one.

QUESTION.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—They can have the floor if they want it, Mr President.
—I ask Senator MacGibbon to ask his question and to ignore the interjections.
—Order! There are far too many interjections from my right. Senator Gietzelt has some difficulty in hearing and he is entitled to hear the question.

—My question concerns the book Padre: Australian Chaplains in Gallipoli and France, authored by the Assistant Director for Research and Publications at the Australian War Memorial, Dr Michael McKernan, whose conduct was strongly defended by the Minister in the Senate yesterday. I ask: Was an Australian War Memorial researcher, Ms Ann Millar, diverted by Dr McKernan for three weeks to work on Padre? Were two Australian War Memorial secretaries, Ms Lyn Lowes and Ms Dot Haines, used by Dr McKernan for typing and word processing of his manuscript during office hours? Did Dr McKernan use Mr Tom Frame, an Australian War Memorial vacation scholar, for additional research during office hours? Finally, under what circumstances were 31 photographs from the Australian War Memorial library used in Padre, and were reproduction fees ever paid to the War Memorial by either Dr McKernan or his publisher, Messrs Allen and Unwin?

—Senator MacGibbon asks a very detailed question in respect of the activities of one of 217 people who work at the Australian War Memorial. I obviously would not have the details necessary to respond to satisfy Senator MacGibbon. I have 13,000 people working in the Department and I would not know whether they use resources for this, that or anything else. All I know is that, if resources were used in respect of any matter of a private nature, that would come within the jurisdiction of the person in charge of the Australian War Memorial, who at that stage would have been the Director, Air Vice-Marshal Flemming. If there were any suggestions that resources of the War Memorial had been improperly used, then it was the responsibility of the Director to draw it to the attention of the Council and/or the Minister. Never on any occasion, as far as I am personally concerned, in the period of almost two years during which the War Memorial has been under my ministerial jurisdiction, have any of these matters been drawn to my attention by anybody associated with the War Memorial.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In the light of that explanation, was the Minister not concerned yesterday, when he presented, with full support, the statutory declaration from Dr McKernan, at the discrepancy between Dr McKernan's statutory declaration and the audit from Arthur Young?

—The honourable senator's assertions do not impress me at all. If he can produce evidence, they will be investigated; but on the basis of attempting continually to smear officers of the Australian War Memorial without any evidence at all, I am not prepared to respond.

—Can the Minister for Education inform the Senate of progress being made in the export of services by Australian educational institutions? What action has the Government taken to encourage institutions to establish and market educational services overseas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to inform the Senate that the Government's relatively new policy of exporting education services is moving along very satisfactorily indeed. For example, there are currently 350 overseas students enrolled in full fee courses here in Australia or off-shore. At this stage about 20 higher education institutions are offering such courses. At the same time, we would like to see even more institutions get involved and more courses offered.

ANSWER.PARA: Those honourable senators who are interested in this very exciting development will be pleased to hear that, to facilitate an increase in activity by the institutions, the Government recently announced new measures to encourage and reward institutions entering the export market. For the next five years higher education institutions will be permitted to retain a part of the capital component of the full fees that they charge overseas students. Under these arrangements institutions will retain the full capital element of fees until the end of 1988, 75 per cent in 1989, and 50 per cent in 1990. Institutions will be free to use this revenue to develop new facilities, which in turn will generate a further capacity for export activity. The Government has also decided that the remaining 50 per cent of the capital component in 1989 and 1990 will be applied through the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to priority capital projects across the higher education sector. It is clearly now very much in the interests of institutions themselves and of the sector generally that they pursue the opportunity for the development of full cost courses.

I am delighted at the response of our institutions. I believe that more of them will respond energetically now that there is an incentive, in terms of the development of their own capital facilities, to do so. In the light of the current debate about the desirability of private entrepreneurs coming into this field, there is really no need, in terms of our export development, to have private operators in the field, since public institutions are showing themselves to be very able and willing to move into this market.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to his tabling yesterday of a statutory declaration from the Assistant Director of the Australian War Memorial, Dr McKernan, denying allegations made against him by the member for the Northern Territory, on the basis of which the Minister rejected Mr Everingham's allegations and described them as scurrilous, defamatory and scandalous. Given the Minister's acceptance of the version contained in the McKernan declaration, I ask whether the Minister will explain why Dr McKernan omitted to mention that a memorandum from the Director of the Memorial to him dated 4 July 1986 stated that neither the research and publications committee nor the Australian War Memorial Council had specifically approved expenditure for or publication of a guide book to the War Memorial; that despite this lack of specific approval, a total of $33,067 had been paid out of Memorial funds at that time; asked why a member of Dr McKernan's staff, Mr Peter Stanley, had been hired on a freelance basis to write the publication, and what were the terms of his contract; and asked why an in-house booklet developed into a glossy, expensive publication by a company controlled by Mr John Ferguson, a Sydney publisher, but also a paid consultant to the War Memorial.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Council of the Australian War Memorial is charged under the Australian War Memorial Act, which was introduced into the Parliament by the previous Government and became law in 1980. So any questions about the administration of the Australian War Memorial rest with the decisions taken by the previous Government. The Act vests the authority for the care, control and management of the Australian War Memorial in the Council. The powers of the Minister are very limited. Consequently, I have little power over the way in which the Australian War Memorial operates. The Council, then, in its day to day operations, reposes the responsibility for the management in the Director, a statutory officer appointed in 1982 for a five-year term. If any of the matters the Opposition wishes to raise in respect of any of the public servants employed by the Australian War Memorial have any substance at all, those matters, of course, become the responsibility of the Council of the Australian War Memorial.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to Mr Everingham's scurrilous attack in the Parliament upon these public servants, I did no more than request from the officers concerned their response. I did not endorse their response, and I do not resile from my responsibilities in that respect. I neither endorsed nor rejected anything. All I did yesterday was table their responses so the Parliament would be aware of how the officers responded to the allegations made. According to section 20, sub-section (2), of the Australian War Memorial Act, the responsibility for these matters rests with the Council.

The Council, of course, has been meeting for 3 1/2 days, and is still meeting, with a view to resolving the difficulties surrounding the Director. I imagine that when that position has been determined, if there is any substance at all in respect of the matters raised by the Opposition or, for that matter any person, about the publications, the bookshop or the research sections of the Australian War Memorial, it will be the responsibility-I will see that it is-of the Council to examine these matters. Honourable senators can rest assured that the Council will accept its responsibilities in these matters now that it is aware of the serious deficiencies that exist in the administration of the War Memorial-deficiencies which caused the Council to request me to appoint an investigator and which obviously led to the situation of the Director being asked to retire.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the Government have any information that can throw further light on the vicious murder of Rolando Olalia, a leading trade union figure and left wing politician in the Philippines? What does the Government think the likely effect of this murder will be on the stability of the Philippines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government has been appalled and shocked by the report of the murder in Manila yesterday of a leading Philippines public figure, Mr Rolando Olalia, who was Chairman of the Partido Ng Bayan, or PNB, and of the trade union grouping Kilusang Mayo Uno, or KMU. On behalf of the Government I wish to express our sympathy to Mr Olalia's family and to Mr Bobby Ortaliz, the Secretary-General of the KMU, who is currently visiting Australia. Mr Olalia's role in the public life of his country brought him into contact with a great number of Australians, particularly Australian trade unionists, and he was a very well known figure. The Australian Government has no further information that I am aware of at this stage in addition to that which has been in the Press, and is, of course, unable to comment on allegations concerning those who might be guilty of the crime. Of course, we hope that the Philippines Government will be able to move quickly to ensure that they are brought to justice.

ANSWER.PARA: To the extent that this crime may be symptomatic of some larger political unrest operating in the Philippines at the moment, I think it should also be said that the Australian Government attaches enormous importance to the efforts being made by the Government of Mrs Aquino to consolidate political stability in the Philippines and to introduce social, economic and political reform and, of course, to restore the full operation of normal democratic processes. We deplore any actions which aim to destabilise the Government of the Philippines and so hinder the Aquino Administration's ability to tackle the very serious problems it faces.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VANUNU AFFAIR: AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney- General. According to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday concerning questions I have on notice regarding possible Australian Security Intelligence Organisation involvement in the Vanunu affair, a spokesman for the Attorney-General said he would not comment on security matters. Can this be taken as an official response to my questions? If so, what possible involvement with Australian security does the matter of nuclear weapons in Israel have? For instance, would it imply some undisclosed connection between Australia and Israel in the development of nuclear weapons? If not, can this response be taken as an open licence for ASIO to meddle in the affairs of other countries, immune from any obligation to inform this Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any questions on notice that may have been asked by Senator Mason on this or any other matter will be the subject of a written answer from the Attorney-General in the usual way. The response that was made yesterday by the Attorney-General's office was consistent with the practice of successive Australian governments of neither confirming nor denying allegations about ASIO, no matter how far fetched or inaccurate those allegations might be. However, in response to some of the more wide-ranging and extravagant parts of Senator Mason's question, it does need to be said that the functions of ASIO are limited by statute to matters concerning the security of Australia and that Mr Justice Hope, in his recent report on Australia's security agencies, found, as I hope Senator Mason has noted, that ASIO had been concerned to ensure that its operations and actions are within its statutory charter.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as Senator Mason refers to the role of Parliament in overseeing the activities of ASIO, Senator Mason will, or should, know-one is never quite sure with Senator Mason-that the accountability of ASIO will be strengthened by measures recently passed by Parliament increasing the role played by the Attorney-General and, of course, by the Parliament itself, through the proposed new committee. Senator Mason will also recall that legislation has recently been passed to establish the office of Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, whose functions will include investigating complaints about the Organisation's conduct. In respect of the filling of that position, an announcement is, I believe, scheduled to be made very shortly indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Which section of the industry is responsible for the wildly erratic prices of petrol from service stations throughout Australia and, in particular, the Brisbane area, where at many of the service stations over the past 10 days the price has moved from 54c a litre to 36c a litre and back again? What motives lie behind such fluctuations, which seem to be uniform? I further ask: What opportunity exists for the Federal Government to intervene to stop this practice? Further, what harm do these changing prices have on the management of petrol stations owned by oil companies, and can any action be taken to protect the motoring public from the confusion that has developed over petrol pricing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it clear, as I have done on numerous previous occasions, that the Commonwealth has no control over the retail petrol market. That is a State responsibility to the extent that the States choose to exercise it. The Prices Surveillance Authority established by the Commonwealth does of course endorse, however, a maximum wholesale price based on examination of oil company costs and profit levels and each of the States accepts at the moment the PSA's recommendations. What the Commonwealth itself does that is crucial, at least so far as the base price is concerned, is set the price for Australian crude oil based on world market prices.

ANSWER.PARA: At the retail level there are many reasons for discounting of the kind that we have witnessed in Queensland in recent times, as in a number of other parts of Australia. It might be instigated by oil companies with excess product or it might be instigated, as it occasionally is, by independent operators with access to spot sales of petrol, or sometimes by the service stations themselves. As far as I am aware, there is no excess supply of petrol in Queensland at present, so I can only assume that increased market share struggling is the reason behind the discounting that has been mentioned by Senator Jones. Once one service station lowers its price its competitors, of course, have to follow quickly or they jeopardise their commercial position. This is because, as is well known, consumer loyalty in the petrol market is a commodity in very short supply indeed and, as a result, there is this great sensitivity to price.

Discounting again tends to be most prevalent in areas of high volume sales so that increased sales can in those circumstances more than offset the reduced profit margin involved. To the extent that service station owners or lessees are supported by oil companies when discount selling is under way, it is usually clear that there are no adverse effects on service station management. However, it is the case that private operators without financial support are in a vulnerable position when discounting of this kind takes place. All I can say, finally, I suppose, is that the public can rest assured that the Commonwealth is doing its bit to minimise the effects of crude oil price changes on petrol prices by offsetting, as we continue to do, increased revenue from crude oil excise as the price of crude gradually goes up by, at the same time, bearing downwards the excise on petroleum products, and certainly we would intend to maintain that policy for the foreseeable future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women to section 40 of the Sex Discrimination Act which effectively removed from the application of that Act anything done by a person in compliance with a number of Acts, including the Marriage Act, for a period of two years from the commencement of the Sex Discrimination Act, which period expired on 1 August 1986. I ask the Minister: Has the Government made a decision to exempt permanently section 11 of the Marriage Act from the application of the Sex Discrimination Act? Does such an exemption confer different rights on men and women in that women can marry at 16 and men not until they are 18? Which women's groups were consulted to come to such a decision? What is the principle which justifies the continuation of this discrimination between men and women in the matter of marriage?

—Senator Vanstone no doubt realises that the administration of the Sex Discrimination Act is the responsibility of the Attorney-General. While I am aware of a number of steps that have been taken to bring various State and Federal laws into line with the provisions of the Act within the two-year period, I do not have information with me specifically answering the effect on the Marriage Act. I will seek that information from the Attorney-General and provide it to Senator Vanstone.
—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Am I to understand from the Minister's answer that, as the Minister responsible effectively for the status of women, she is unaware of such a move?
—I will not answer that question.
—The Minister cares not to answer the question.

—Is the Minister for Education aware that there is considerable concern among Queensland external students opposed to a recommendation made by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, which proposes serious restriction of courses offered from the University of Queensland? Can the Minister assure external students that any necessary rationalisation will not lead to a closure of Australia's pioneer in the field of external studies nor will Queensland external students be directed to universities in other States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the recommendations of the very wide-ranging efficiency and effectiveness review of higher education was that there be a series of rationalisations in the external studies area. The aim of those rationalisations would be to concentrate expertise in the distance education area and to provide better access, better follow-up and better opportunity for tutorial assistance and so on to external students. The efficiency and effectiveness review is, as I said, a very wide-ranging report. It deals with an enor- mous number of matters concerning efficiencies involved in the operation of higher education, and the Government has not yet given consideration to the recommendations in the report. We will be doing so shortly. Indeed, on 25 November, I think it is-I will correct this if it is wrong-there is to be a major seminar on the efficiency and effectiveness review sponsored jointly by the Tertiary Education Commission and the Institute of Public Administration.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's consideration of these matters is in the very early stages. Certainly no decisions have been taken and I think we are some distance from making decisions on the recommendations. Certainly Senator Reynolds herself, as a member of the Government, will be able to make comments on the review. I am aware that there is a campaign amongst external students, particularly those at the University of Queensland. All I would like to say in response to the campaign at this stage is that, whatever decisions we make, they will be decisions in the interests of improving access by students to external studies and improving the quality of external studies. Those two criteria would certainly be the basis from which we would consider the CTEC recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to either the Leader of the Government in the Senate or to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Has the Government made a decision to intervene before the Supreme Court of New South Wales in support of the United Kingdom Government's moves to suppress the publication of Peter Wright's book Conspiracies of Silence? If so, why? Is it a fact that Wright's book adds nothing new to the public debate about the role of Sir Roger Hollis which has not already been exposed by Chapman Pincher in the about to be published new biography of Anthony Blunt and others? Are the people of Australia not entitled to know the full details of Hollis's role in the establishment of their own security organisation, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation? Is not the Australian public's interest best served by the open discussion of these issues rather than by the techniques of censorship and suppression which are always ultimately doomed to failure?

First of all, the Australia-New Zealand resolution on a comprehensive test ban, which reaffirms the fundamental importance of the comprehensive test ban treaty and develops a program of action to achieve it, received the highest number of positive votes of all five resolutions, that is to say, 117 votes. This support included the majority of Western non-nuclear states as well as the Soviet Union and its allies. TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to my notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Children's Services Ordinance 1986, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 13 of 1986 and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed.

I would like to explain to the Senate the reasons why I took over this motion of disallowance from the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. The Ordinance is in my view, and in the view of many other experts in this area, the most far-reaching piece of reforming legislation about children and families that has been made by a Minister for the Australian Capital Territory for almost 20 years. It is based on the Australian Law Reform Commission's Report on Child Welfare which was almost three years in the making. It was tabled in 1981 and is almost 500 pages long. The Ordinance itself has been in preparation for over five years and contains close to 200 sections. The Ordinance is obviously not just another piece of municipal ministerial legislation for Canberra; it provides for a fundamental restructuring of the way in which the most vulnerable people in our society-our children-are to be dealt with by two of the most powerful forces in our society, the Public Service bureaucracy and the courts.

The Ordinance establishes a Children Services Council; a standing committee of that Council; a statutory office of Youth Advocate; and a Children's Court. It provides a complete code as to how children accused of crime or in need of care are to be proceeded against or dealt with in terms of their arrest, their detention, being interviewed, taking fingerprints and blood samples and being sentenced or put in care. Officials are given wide and certainly necessary powers to enter premises where children are on probation or subject to supervision orders. The Director of Welfare is to have large powers to deal with children in custody. The Ordinance contains detailed and far-reaching provisions regulating children's day care services and the employment of children. The Youth Advocate-that is an interesting statutory officeholder-will be a person possessed of the most remarkable range of conflicting powers and duties, as an administrator, an investigator, a collector of evidence, as an adjudicator or in effect a judge of that evidence, a prosecutor in care proceedings, a defender of children, a welfare officer, a family counsellor, and a public spokesperson on child welfare issues. Although called a Youth Advocate, the incumbent will very often be in conflict with children and parents. This statutory office will be at once the focal point of important powers and discretions and great stresses and tensions.

I need to make one thing clear. I am not passing judgment on these innovations. I am not saying they are wrong or misguided. I am not saying that they do not reflect the honest and serious commitment of the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) and his child welfare advisers to try to do the right thing by parents, families and children in this city and Territory. However, we cannot get away from the fact that this Ordinance breaks new ground. It contains a highly innovative mixture of legal, administrative, judicial, custodial and welfare measures and procedures. The subjects of these new proceedings, of these novel proposals, will be children who have committed crimes, who have been abused or who need to be controlled. The subjects of these new departures will be broken families, families in crisis, parents in strife and conflict. If the unique mixture of provisions in this Ordinance is in practice a mismatch, if the new child welfare scheme does not function as it is hoped it should, the real victims will be those children and families who need the most help.

As I said this morning, because of these implications the operation of the Ordinance must be subject to a real ongoing review. The Minister has said he will review it, but long before four years are up this debate, these concerns, will all have disappeared from the forefront of anybody's mind. If the Ordinance does not work easily it will be made to work uneasily and everyone will adjust his level of expectations to perhaps second rate procedures and mechanisms for helping children in trouble. However, if a sunset clause had been put into the legislation, that single fact on its own would guarantee, firstly, that the practice and procedures under the Ordinance would be regularly and consistently looked at and appraised over the four-year period and not put on the back burner. Secondly, flaws would be sought out and rectified, not merely ignored or accommodated. Thirdly, statistics, reactions and evaluations would be collected and assessed on a continuing basis and not merely sporadically; and finally, amendments and adjustments would be made to make the Ordinance fit the facts of children's lives and not insist that those lives be made to meet any possibly unrealistic requirements of the Ordinance.

If a sunset clause were part of the law, the Australian Capital Territory community would have a guarantee that it would not be left burdened for, say, 20 years with legislation which may not work out in practice. If the Australian Democrats had been prepared to support this motion, the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) would certainly have agreed to put a four-year sunset clause into the Ordinance and there would be no question of disallowance. In fact what has happened is that the Democrats have been snowed. The Public Service got on to the Democrats last night and said: `Isn't it a terrible thing. The Liberal and National parties are going ahead with the disallowance of this Ordinance. This Ordinance will be disallowed. What a terrible thing'. The poor old Democrats fell for the three-card trick. Instead of saying to the Public Service `That is nonsense, the Minister will agree if the Opposition parties stand firm', they fell for the three-card trick and the result is that they have not supported with me the proposal before the Minister that a sunset clause be inserted.

Without a clause the Australian Capital Territory community runs the risk that in four or 14 years time these child welfare laws will be as out of date and inappropriate as the 1957 Ordinance is to date. The ongoing amendments needed to make the Ordinance work, to justify its retention after four years, will not be in place because there will have been no pressing obligation to put them in place. Since the Minister would have agreed to a sunset clause if he had had to, nothing would have been lost by supporting this motion up to this stage. The Ordinance would not have been lost, the machinery would still all be in place, but the sunset clause would represent a vital means of quality control and a vital means of bureaucratic accountability to the highest standards of child welfare. Because the Democrats will not support this motion, the Senate has given away, perhaps for another 20 years, the power to ensure that Australian Capital Territory child care law is properly and adequately monitored and reviewed. As a Senate, we should have insisted upon that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has already been the subject of some discussion by leave earlier today. I explained then why the Government rejected the concept of a sunset clause and accordingly opposed the disallowance motion now being taken up by Senator Lewis. I want to say a couple of things again for the record.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an important piece of legislation concerned with the welfare of children in the Australian Capital Territory, as Senator Lewis acknowledged. The Ordinance is being implemented in stages and it will, in fact, be some time yet before its full dimension is in place. It has been developed as a result of a Law Reform Commission report produced in 1980 and lengthy community consultations before and since. It is also worth saying that the Ordinance had unanimous support of the major parties of the former Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly-that is to say the Australian Labor Party, the Liberals and the Australian Democrats-and it clearly has the backing of the Australian Capital Territory community. The Government is concerned to ensure the success of the Ordinance and will monitor closely the effects of those parts of the Ordinance in operation. The Children's Services Council set up by the Ordinance will provide annual reports to the Minister and the Parliament and will be an authoritative source of reporting on the progress of the Ordinance. The Council will be broadly representative of people with an interest in the operation of the Ordinance-for example the Chief Magistrate, police, youth advocate, director of welfare and representatives of the Health Authority and the Schools Authority.

The Government this morning through me indicated its willingness for a review to take place into the operations of the Ordinance after it has been in place long enough for a reasonable foundation for such a review to be made. We are thinking in terms of four or five years after the initial implementation of it. On matters as sensitive and as important as this, it is hardly likely that the matter will disappear from sight in the absence of the discipline of a sunset clause in the way that Senator Lewis is asserting. There are all sorts of other reasons which I mentioned this morning, and will not repeat, why a sunset clause is inappropriate when such wide ranging and central administrative machinery as this is what is in issue. For all those reasons, I suggest that the Senate reject the disallowance motion and ensure that this Ordinance will come into force.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have never really understood the role of the Parliament, have you?

—I have understood that the honourable senator has totally misunderstood and misread the support that exists for this matter and misrepresented, as I understand it, the position of a number of other people in this place and on committees as to what their position is. Now the honourable senator is in a state of acute and understandable disappointment of the course that has been followed. Under those circumstances I think it would be appropriate if the honourable senator just shut up and let this matter go through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In what I hope are the dying stages of this debate, I rise to express the strongest support on behalf of the Australian Democrats for the Australian Capital Territory Children's Services Ordinance. I think it is necessary to underline the history of this Ordinance. What we have really had in the Australian Capital Territory-as the report from the Standing Committee on Health, Housing and Welfare from the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly said-is a set of concepts and procedures developed at the beginning of this century.

SPEECH.PARA: It pleased us greatly that the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances saw the wisdom of looking at the whole Ordinance, accepting the Ordinance as it stood, and accepting the advice of one of the people submitting information to the House of Assembly inquiry, the former commissioner in charge of the Law Reform Commission's inquiry into child welfare law in the Australian Capital Territory, Mr Seymour. He cautioned very strongly against piecemeal changes to what is, as the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has said, a very complicated Ordinance. It is complicated because its basis is so far back in history. The motivation of the Australian Democrats' strong support has been questioned this afternoon. The motivation is, as it always should be, the interests of the people concerned in the Ordinance, in this case the children of the Australian Capital Territory. In turn, we could question the motivation of people who have been prepared to tinker with something, to deal with it in a piecemeal fashion and suggest that perhaps concepts and procedures of the turn of the century are more comfortable than concepts and procedures which belong here at present and which are far more appropriate to the children of the Australian Capital Territory.

The wide community support and input into the development of this Ordinance should not and was not overlooked by the Australian Democrats or by bodies such as the Australian Capital Territory Council of Social Service, the Law Reform Commission, the Chief Magistrate, the Australian Capital Territory Health Commission and the Children's Court and it had the endorsement of the House of Assembly. We have taken that into account along with consideration for the children of the Australian Capital Territory. As Senator Lewis has said, this ordinance breaks new ground. It is innovative. Finally, after a tremendously long history of detailed work, it is taking the children of the Australian Capital Territory into the twentieth century. There is no question-I think it is incredible that the Opposition could question this-that those people and groups who have already put so much into the development of this Ordinance will let it drop and will not be concerned to see how it works or to do anything about it if there are problems. I am not referring here to this Government, the next government, this Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) or the next Minister. I am referring to the people in the Australian Capital Territory who have put so much work into this Ordinance. I think it does no credit to the Opposition at all to suggest that these people would just drop it and lose their concern overnight for the children of the Australian Capital Territory. The Australian Democrats do not believe that that will happen.

As to the very strong belief in the mechanism of the sunset clause, if the people promoting the welfare of children in the Australian Capital Territory are imperfect so too are sunset clauses, particularly, one could say, in the hands of those public servants to whom we have been accused of being beholden, rather than, as we are, to the children of the Australian Capital Territory. Sunset clauses can be used as excuses for inaction, not necessarily always as motivators for action. It did strike me as interesting that Senator Lewis, by way of interjection, seemed to be proposing a variety of different times for a sunset clause. I thought he was after four years but I heard him say five. Who knows? All I know is that we have an ordinance for the children of the Australian Capital Territory which will bring opportunities for children of the Australian Capital Territory into the twentieth century. Although the Ordinance may not work perfectly all the time I am certain that we have, as Senator Lewis himself said, an innovative proposal for the children of the Australian Capital Territory which, no doubt, will serve as a model in other areas and we heartily endorse its passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just about everything that needs to be said has been said on this matter. But there is some background that I think is relevant in the light of the comments of Senator Powell. Our concern in suggesting a sunset clause is to make sure that the people in Canberra, who we know will still monitor the Children's Services Ordinance will have a forum in which their concerns can be expressed. That is the reason for a sunset clause, not, as was suggested, the belief that the people of Canberra will not continue to take an interest. Nothing could be further from the truth.
