Needless to say, one tends to concentrate on the areas where one is concerned about negatives. But, in opening my remarks, I wish to acknowledge in a substantial way that the Opposition has supported the general direction of industry policies in a narrow sense-that is, the policies which are administered by this Department-although we have continually expressed our concern about the failure of the Government to provide an appropriate economic framework for the policies which are being put in place.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the simplest way of explaining that would be to refer to the recent decision of the Government with respect to the chemicals industry where very significant reductions in protection have been put forward by the Government, more significant, in fact, than those recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission. Indeed, since its interim report was put down, where some allowance was made for the substantial contribution to our imports by developing countries, I think it would be fair to say that the Government has wound up making decisions with respect to the chemical industry which will put that industry under a great deal of pressure. I have little doubt that Ministers in the Government would have been concerned about that, not least the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, who is at the table. But we have a situation where the government, in a programmed way, is reducing tariffs in that area, as one example.

The Government's general direction will not get a substantial quarrel from the Opposition. However, there is a very deep concern on the part of the Opposition that, for example, the Government will put the chemical industry in a position where it is receiving less protection than equivalent industries in competitor countries. At the same time the Government is not doing enough to ensure that the industry can compete. When the chemical industry faced the prospect of the Government's decision it took the trouble to point out to the Government that a series of cost burdens on the industry put it at a disadvantage compared with industries in other countries. The industry drew attention to a whole range of things, including the Government's taxation measures, the inefficiencies of transport in Australia-for example, the very high cost of coastal shipping is a significant cost burden on elements of the chemical industry-and the restrictions in the taxation area and a whole lot of other things. The labour market was another very important area where restrictive practices and very high labour costs put it at a disadvantage.

The fundamental point of difference between the Opposition and the Government in this matter is that we believe that, if the Government is going to take industries, such as the chemical industry, and say: `You must be more competitive; you have to face up to a much more open market situation', there is a very heavy obligation on the Government to do something about those cost burdens which make it very difficult for Australian industry to survive. The chemical industry made the point that, whilst it might receive assistance to the tune of some $200m through the tariff, it suffered what it saw as cost disabilities equal to $400m because of these various things, many of which are caused by government itself at both the State and Federal level.

The first point that I wish to make is that the Government, in its administration of industry policies, has fallen woefully short of accepting the strong, reciprocal obligation which rests on it, if it is to pursue an opening up of Australian industry to international competition. We believe that that is the direction in which to move but there is a very strong reciprocal obligation on the Government to do something about the cost disabilities which are suffered by Australian industry.

That really takes me to the second area of concern that I have, which is that it seems that in a number of areas where the Government has taken initiatives that have had the support of the Opposition the moves that the Government has taken are running out of steam. The best example that we have had of that recently is in the steel industry. The Government is very proud of the fact that, under its steel plan, there has been a very considerable improvement in productivity. During the early period of this Government there was a very considerable improvement in the level of industrial disputes; that is, there was a drop in the level of industrial disputes. Of course, there was a reduction in employment. But I think most people in the Parliament now agree that, as far as blue collar industries are concerned, unless there are reductions in employment in those industries, they will not compete or survive. The choice is between a reduction in total employment or no blue collar industries.

If we look at the employment record of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, we find a decline in industrial employment everywhere, including in those countries that have a thriving manufacturing industry. The interesting thing is that the level of unemployment in those countries in general is proportional to the drop in blue collar employment. In other words, the more quickly a manufacturing sector becomes efficient, and the more efficient the manufacturing sector is, the smaller proportion of the work force it tends to employ and yet there will be a lower level of unemployment. It is a quite extraordinary situation that has to be thought about in Australia. At least some sections of manufacturing industry, and of course trade unions involved in manufacturing industry, find it terribly difficult to face up to the need for a constant search for greater productivity, often at the expense of a reduced work force.

I congratulate the Government on acknowledging that in the steel industry it was necessary to have a thinning down, a fining down of the work force. The fact is that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is now running, I think, the second most profitable steel industry in the world. That means that there is a real future for the steel industry in this country and for those people who make their livelihood from it. There is a need to accept that general direction. There is no quarrel between the Government and the Opposition to that point. The quarrel begins when one sees, as I said a few minutes ago, that what is being done by the Government appears to be running out of puff, out of steam. That is reflected in the report of the Steel Industry Authority which the Minister brought into the Parliament just a few weeks ago. It is reflected in the very substantial increase in industrial disputes over the last 12-month period. In the various six-month periods defined in the Steel Industry Authority report there are increases ranging up to 600 per cent in the level of industrial disputes. There are figures of 250, 300 and so on. I will not cite the exact figures but there are very substantial increases.

What is even more serious is that there seems to be a considerable hardening of attitude against further productivity increases. That is a very important warning sign for the Government and for Australia because the reality is that Australia in manufacturing does not have to make a quantum jump on to a new plateau of performance. What we have to do is to get on to a rising graph that continues to rise. In other words, we have to accept that our task in the future is to improve productivity continually, and accept that at the work place it is the common interest of management and labour to arrive at the most efficient work practices possible.

The situation in the steel industry, after a very promising start, is that attacks on work practices seem doomed to failure unless the changes in work practices being sought are related to new technology or new investment. That really is not good enough. I enter into the debate on this point because I believe there is a totally common interest between BHP and its work force to see that slow-down really put aside and a genuine attack, a continuing attack, on work practices carried out, and a commitment by both management and labour to a continuing improvement in productivity and efficiency. That is the attitude that has to become the standard attitude in manufacturing industry, whether in a large industry like steel or in a very small plant.

We are not pursuing international competitors who are static. They are steeply increasing their levels of efficiency year by year and we are engaged in the pursuit of them. It is interesting to find that in a country such as Japan, which is having to restructure its industries to meet its economic situation at the moment-that was also referred to by the Minister in the chamber recently-there is an acceptance that manufacturing industry has to achieve continual productivity increases and that in general there will be an accompanying reduction in work force numbers. The important social point that goes with that is that that does not mean increased overall unemployment; but quite the reverse.

It seems to be that, if one can get manufacturing industry to the level of efficiency that can be obtained by a country such as Japan, one is likely to have a much lower rate of overall unemployment than a country such as the United Kingdom which has had the slowest rate of reduction of blue collar work force. The United Kingdom stands as the other end example, if you like-an example of a very slow reduction in the blue collar work force. I know that Senator McIntosh, who is in the chamber, has a great interest in this and would want to see those jobs maintained. But this is a country where there has been a relatively slow reduction in the blue collar work force and yet there is 13 per cent unemployment. The facts speak for themselves and they suggest that the Government's industry policy really does need a bit of a boost. It needs a recharge and renewal of energy and enthusiasm to get some of the changes that were under way moving again. I do not think that the Minister or the Government can accept that the job has been done. There is a serious risk that in 1986 we will see a hardening of the arteries again and a lack of progress that will really do us great harm in the future.

The next area of concern to me is in the approach that the Government is adopting towards industry in a number of cases where there is an excessively bureaucratic element. I have criticised elsewhere the heavy engineering plan, again not because of its general direction but because, instead of fostering the idea that at the work place itself there has to be the greater pursuit of efficiency, the Government is setting up committees which are defining which work practices should be tackled.

The attitude being adopted is that the Government has to put up some money to achieve improvements in work practices. That is pathetic. It is ludicrously wrong. We will shortly have a piece of legislation before us-it has been introduced by the Minister-in which the Government will put up, I think, $6m in bounties, really as a bribe to say: `If we put up $6m in bounties, will you trade unions stop engaging in restrictive work practices in respect of ship repairs?' I put it very seriously to the Government that we do not have the money to pay for that sort of exercise. If we want to pay money to Senator Gietzelt's veterans, to the poor, to the disabled and to the other people who are supposedly the natural constituency of the Australian Labor Party, and who are certainly a constituency about whom the Liberal Party of Australia is concerned, we cannot afford to bribe people simply to do sensible things. But that is the situation. That is one of the trends and tendencies within the Government's industry policy that needs to be watched with great care.

I will just say something else about the heavy engineering plan. The whole problem is that, by ensuring a tripartite approach of trade union, employer and government, part of the difficulty is that introduced into the equation are people who have no direct interest in the outcomes. In closing, because I have nearly finished my time on this, I remind the Government of what was said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Incentive.

—Senator McIntosh uses the expression `incentive'. That is precisely the theme that was put forward by Mr Charles Fitzgibbon in one of those papers that has received a lot of attention over the last year. He made the point that the performance of the Australian work force will not be improved if we pay people who perform badly in exactly the same way as we pay people who perform well. He entered a plea for the need to introduce greater incentives into the system. That acknowledgment of the direct importance of the rewards to individuals that accrue from productive work flies in the face of the Government's pattern of having trade unions, that are not directly related to the interests of a particular work place, involved in on the ground issues such as changes in work practices required in a particular enterprise. In other words, the Government is adopting an unduly bureaucratic approach to these matters instead of saying, as indeed the Minister said in his comments to Estimates Committee A:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think it is the Government's job to tell companies how to improve those things . . .

I agree with that: It is not the Government's job, nor is it a particular trade union's job, to tell people how to improve those things; it is the job of the company and its work force. Again I quote from the Hansard of the Estimates Committee of 16 September in which Senator Button said:
. . . it is important to put in place the right incentives and then industries will do those things for themselves. That is all I am saying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia's technological base, unfortunately, has not kept abreast of that of our more aggressive trading partners. Recently Barry Jones described Australia as a technological museum. I am not really sure whether this is a criticism of his shortcomings in that area or whether it is a criticism of the current Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. One of the few good features to come from the Government recently was its policy, which it cribbed from the Liberal Party of Australia, of a 150 per cent research incentive. One of the unfortunate features of this carrot has been the relatively small number of manufacturers who have taken up, by way of registration for this tax concession, research and development. I ask the Minister to answer the following question: How many manufacturers to date have registered to take advantage of this research and development contribution that he has put forward?

SPEECH.PARA: One of the difficulties of Australian manufacturing is that, certainly in the last 20 years, exports of manufactured goods as a percentage of total exports have increased from only about 13 per cent to 24 per cent, which compares with an average of something like 60 per cent in most other Western nations. I acknowledge that there are difficulties for manufacturers in the Australian market because of the small scale of the domestic market. Small runs cannot always justify the capital investment or the investment in technology which is necessary to improve processes and to develop new products. Manufacturers certainly have to look to world markets and invest in technology. We really have to get Australian industry more motivated to develop overseas markets. I must hand the Minister a bouquet on his recent trip to Japan with a few aggressive marketeers. We must develop a positive market approach and product-orientated action. Going one step further along that chain, we must then develop sources of technology and place greater emphasis on that, and therefore allocate more of our resources to ensure that we have the appropriate technology for industry. That is on the positive side.

The Minister and his colleagues continue to laud the positive effects on manufacturing of the devaluation of the Australian dollar, and we acknowledge that a number of manufacturers have adapted and exploited this potential against some pretty heavy competition. The view I put to the Senate is that those bold entrepreneurs who have gone out-in the glass industry I think of Pilkington ACI Ltd and these sorts of firms-and used their technology and grabbed markets and who are now supplying companies such as Daimler Benz in Germany and others in Japan could soon be in trouble because they are working with pretty fine margins. They will be in trouble because of Australia's high rate of domestic inflation. This inflation is significantly higher now than that of our trading competitors. The short term effects of the devaluation of the dollar-they are short term effects, let us acknowledge it-I believe will soon be eroded, within a couple of years, as a result of this creeping domestic inflation.

I believe the Government has to put a greater emphasis on keeping down its rate of internal inflation. This is difficult when a country devalues because certain inflationary effects arise, not from wage increases but from the effects of the devaluation. This domestic inflation is a major problem, not only for those who are entering for the first time this export market with very fine margins but also for those who are already established in it because they could be losing their export opportunities to other firms. The big problem we have to face is inflation, and I do not think the Government is putting enough emphasis on it at the moment.

The other reason for my not thinking manufacturers will get the real benefits from this devaluation is that many of the foreign suppliers have kept their export prices to Australia in terms of their own currencies. I think we have problems.
Consideration interrupted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Treasurer detail how the Taxation Office will assess charitable employers who are providing disabled people with essential services free of charge.
(2) Will charitable organisations be exempt from fringe benefits tax where their work is clearly associated with service delivery to disabled people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Public benevolent institutions will be exempted from fringe benefits taxation on the non-cash benefits provided to their employees. The phrase `public benevolent institution' does not have a statutory definition but is generally understood to be an institution for the relief of poverty, sickness, suffering, distress, misfortune, destitution or helplessness. Public benevolent institutions have, as a common feature, the giving of relief freely to those who are in need of it and are unable to care for themselves. Organisations which do not satisfy these requirements will be subject to tax on benefits provided to their employees in accordance with the valuation rules set out in the legislation.
(2) Yes, provided the organisations qualify as public benevolent institutions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 20 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the names, descriptions and salaries of the ministerial, parliamentary and other staff who accompanied the Australian Labor Party's Rural Task Force, headed by Mr Barry Cunningham MP, in its recent visits around Australia.
(2) What staff travel was involved and against which head was it charged.
(3) If ministerial staff were seconded to assist the inquiry, what travel authority was used to pay for travel which did not involve accompanying a Minister on official business.
(4) What accommodation expenses incurred by Parliamentarians and staff were met by the Commonwealth.
(5) What travel expenses incurred by Parliamentarians and staff were met by the Commonwealth.
(6) What payment arrangements were made.
(7) What other expenses incurred by Parliamentarians and staff were met by the Commonwealth.
(8) What services and facilities were supplied by the National Media Liaison Service.
(9) What was the cost to the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) The entitlements of Senators and Members to travel and the payment of travelling allowance for such travel is determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. My Department has no knowledge of travel arrangements made for members of the Rural Task Force and received no information concerning accompanying staff, if any. Any staff travel at official expense which may have occurred as a result of travel undertaken by the Task Force would have been made in accordance with the normal travel entitlements of the staff concerned.

(4) to (7) Travelling allowances for Senators and Members are paid by the Parliamentary Departments. My Department meets the cost of transport expenses for Senators and Members and transport expenses and travelling allowances for staff. My Department has no knowledge of payments made to Senators, Members and staff, if any, in connection with the Task Force.

(8) and (9) Advice from the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism is that the National Media Liaison Service office in Perth arranged two media conferences for the Task Force during its visit to Western Australia in April. The office also acted as a media contact point for the Task Force. The National Media Liaison Service office in Melbourne distributed two media statements and assisted with media liaison during the Task Force's visit to Victorian regional centres in mid-June. Because of the nature of the services provided, the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism states that it is not possible to accurately estimate the cost of the services provided by the National Media Liaison Service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the special temporary, or bereavement, allowance for age pensioners regarded as assessable for income tax purposes; if so-
(a) does a payment of this allowance require some age pensioners who have not been required to submit taxation returns for many years to once again complete a return; and
(b) as this allowance is paid to help a bereaved pensioner spouse through a difficult period, will the Government consider making the allowance non-taxable.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Special temporary allowance (STA) or bereavement allowance is paid to age pensioners and certain other social security recipients on the death of the pensioner's spouse. The STA is subject to income tax if paid to a person of age pension age. Because of the receipt of the allowance a pensioner may be required to pay income tax and submit an income tax return when, without the allowance, his or her income would have been below the tax free threshold for pensioners and, therefore, non-taxable.
(b) The honourable senator can be assured that his proposal to exempt the allowance from tax has been noted and will be considered when the matter is next reviewed.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Marine Sciences and Technologies Grants Scheme

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 7 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the Budget for the Marine Sciences and Technologies Grants Scheme cut by approximately 25 per cent; if so can the Minister for Science advise the reasons for such a severe cut to this Scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The allocation for the Marine Sciences and Technologies Grants Scheme has been reduced from $3.842m in 1986 to $3.052m for 1987 a reduction of 20.58%. In the end the competition was between maintaining the Scheme at the increased level of recent years and ensuring that the Australian Research Grants Scheme (ARGS) would have a real increase of 10% for 1987. On this occasion, ARGS was given priority.
The amount available for 1987 has contributed to the continuation of marine sciences and technologies research. 102 well refereed projects will be supported with grants in 1987.

I have recently received from the Australian Marine Sciences and Technologies Advisory Committee (AMSTAC) its report on the operation of the MST Grants Scheme. I have stated that the Scheme will continue in 1988. Decisions on the longer term funding of the Scheme will be taken when I have considered the recommendations contained in the AMSTAC Report.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 20 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has funding for the Marine Sciences and Technologies Grants Scheme (MSTGS) been reduced by 25 per cent for 1987 and is it intended to abolish the scheme in 1988.

(2) Will this have a detrimental effect on the development of marine aquaculture which is a technique of importance in South East Asia for a number of species of marine fish and of growing interest in Australia.
(3) Is there a major need to expand our marine research capacity and develop and market new products.

(4) Have laboratory facilities been developed at the Department of Civil Engineering, University of Queensland involving a coastal processes wave basin and was this facility completely designed and built by Australians at a considerable saving in cost compared with purchasing equipment from established source of supply overseas.
(5) Will research that is being undertaken provide essential understanding of the mainland coastal and Great Barrier Reef environments required by coastal and marine park managers.

(6) Will this research also assist engineers concerned with the design of marine structures such as jetties, breakwaters, boat harbours, navigational aids, weather stations and reef viewing platforms.

(7) Are conditions on the Australian coasts and reefs generally very different from those in other parts of the world, so that the results of research conducted in European or American waters are often not applicable.

(8) Will the abolition or continued curtailment of the MSTGS mean that significant current and potential research of practical relevance to coastal communities and industries, particularly the tourist industry, cannot be carried out.

(9) Would it not be in the national interest to expand the MSTGS, so that Australia can benefit from continuing research on the development of marine aquaculture and into the use and conservation of Australia's coastal environment and marine resources.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The allocation for the Marine Sciences and Technologies (MST) Grants Scheme has been reduced from $3.842m in 1986 to $3.052m for 1987, a reduction of 20.58%. In the end the competition was between maintaining the Scheme at the increased level of recent years and ensuring that the Australian Research Grants Scheme (ARGS) would have a real increase of 10% for 1987. On this occasion, ARGS was given priority. I have announced that support for the Scheme will continue in 1988.

(2) Grants under the MST Grants Scheme are awarded on a competitive basis. 102 well refereed projects will be supported with grants in 1987. Marine aquaculture is not given special consideration under the Scheme.

(3) The MST Grants Scheme was established in 1979 to fulfil a need perceived by the government for a viable, effective and productive Australian effort in the marine sciences and technologies. The Scheme has been highly successful and a number of major research groups have now been firmly established in this country. It could be expected that these groups should be in a position now to become more self-supporting and to seek funds from other sources.
(4) I do not have a detailed knowledge of the marine facilities available at the University of Queensland.
(5) Yes.
(6) Yes.
(7) In general there are some similarities but Australia has quite a unique coastal environment, half of which is in the tropical area and includes the Great Barrier Reef.
(9) No. It was never intended by Government that the MST Grants Scheme should be the sole source of funds for marine sciences and technologies in Australia.

It should be pointed out that expenditure of Commonwealth funds on civil marine science research and development has increased from $12.26 million in 1978-79 to $49.87 million in 1985-86, and even in real dollars this is a substantial increase.
